entry.title: Nakayama Lemma
entry.content:
啥都能水系列

茴字的四种写法之Nakayama lemma. 大定理的最后几个部分和一般的Nakayama lemma (finite 版本)差的有点远了, 但是还是抄上来了.

Nakayama Lemma

Lemma 1 (Existence of adjoint matrix). Let RRR be a ring. Let n≥mn \geq mn≥m. Let AAA be an n×mn \times mn×m matrix with coefficients in RRR. Let J⊂RJ \subset RJ⊂R be the ideal generated by the m×mm \times mm×m minors of AAA.

For any f∈Jf \in Jf∈J there exists a m×nm \times nm×n matrix BBB such that BA=f1m×mBA = f 1_{m \times m}BA=f1m×m​.

Proof

Proof. For I⊂{1,…,n}I \subset \{1, \ldots, n\}I⊂{1,…,n} with ∣I∣=m|I| = m∣I∣=m, we denote by EIE_IEI​ the m×nm \times nm×n matrix of the projection

R⊕n=⨁i∈{1,…,n}R⟶⨁i∈IRR^{\oplus n} = \bigoplus\nolimits_{i \in \{1, \ldots, n\}} R\longrightarrow \bigoplus\nolimits_{i \in I} RR⊕n=⨁i∈{1,…,n}​R⟶⨁i∈I​R

and set AI=EIAA_I = E_I AAI​=EI​A, i.e., AIA_IAI​ is the m×mm \times mm×m matrix whose rows are the rows of AAA with indices in III. Let BIB_IBI​ be the adjugate (transpose of cofactor) matrix to AIA_IAI​, i.e., such that AIBI=BIAI=det⁡(AI)1m×mA_I B_I = B_I A_I = \det(A_I) 1_{m \times m}AI​BI​=BI​AI​=det(AI​)1m×m​. The m×mm \times mm×m minors of AAA are the determinants det⁡AI\det A_IdetAI​ for all the I⊂{1,…,n}I \subset \{1, \ldots, n\}I⊂{1,…,n} with ∣I∣=m|I| = m∣I∣=m. If f∈Jf \in Jf∈J then we can write f=∑cIdet⁡(AI)f = \sum c_I \det(A_I)f=∑cI​det(AI​) for some cI∈Rc_I \in RcI​∈R. Set B=∑cIBIEIB = \sum c_I B_I E_IB=∑cI​BI​EI​ to see that the lemma holds. ◻

Now we give a large version of Nakayama lemma.

Theorem 1 (Nakayama Lemma). Let RRR be a ring, R\mathfrak{R}R is the Jacobson radical and a\mathfrak{a}a is an ideal. MMM is an RRR-module.

  1. If aM=M\mathfrak{a}M=MaM=M and MMM is finite generated, then there is x∈Rx\in Rx∈R s.t. x−1∈ax-1\in \mathfrak{a}x−1∈a and xM=0xM=0xM=0.

  2. If aM=M\mathfrak{a}M=MaM=M and MMM is finite generated, a⊂R\mathfrak{a}\subset \mathfrak{R}a⊂R, then M=0M=0M=0.

  3. If N,N′⊂MN,N'\subset MN,N′⊂M, M=N+aN′M=N+\mathfrak{a}N'M=N+aN′, N′N'N′ is finite generated, then there is x∈Rx\in Rx∈R s.t. x−1∈ax-1\in \mathfrak{a}x−1∈a and xM⊂NxM\subset NxM⊂N, Mx=NxM_{x}=N_{x}Mx​=Nx​.

  4. If N,N′⊂MN,N'\subset MN,N′⊂M, M=N+aN′M=N+\mathfrak{a}N'M=N+aN′, N′N'N′ is finite generated, a⊂R\mathfrak{a}\subset \mathfrak{R}a⊂R, then M=NM=NM=N.

  5. Let f:N→Mf:N\to Mf:N→M be a homomorphism, fˉ:N/aN→M/aM\bar{f}:N /\mathfrak{a}N\to M /\mathfrak{a}Mfˉ​:N/aN→M/aM is surjective. If MMM is finite generated then there is x∈Rx\in Rx∈R s.t. x−1∈ax-1\in \mathfrak{a}x−1∈a and fx:Nx→Mxf_{x}:N_{x}\to M_{x}fx​:Nx​→Mx​ is surjective.

  6. Let f:N→Mf:N\to Mf:N→M be a homomorphism, fˉ:N/aN→M/aM\bar{f}:N /\mathfrak{a}N\to M /\mathfrak{a}Mfˉ​:N/aN→M/aM is surjective. If MMM is finite generated and a⊂R\mathfrak{a}\subset\mathfrak{R}a⊂R, then fff is surjective.

  7. If x1,…,xn∈Mx_{1},\dots, x_{n}\in Mx1​,…,xn​∈M generates M/aMM /\mathfrak{a}MM/aM and MMM is finite generated, then there’s x∈Rx\in Rx∈R s.t. x−1∈ax-1\in \mathfrak{a}x−1∈a and x1,…,xnx_{1},\dots, x_{n}x1​,…,xn​ generates MxM_{x}Mx​ as an RxR_{x}Rx​-module.

  8. If x1,…,xn∈Mx_{1},\dots, x_{n}\in Mx1​,…,xn​∈M generates M/aMM /\mathfrak{a}MM/aM, MMM is finite generated and a⊂R\mathfrak{a}\subset\mathfrak{R}a⊂R, then MMM is generated by x1,…,xnx_{1},\dots, x_{n}x1​,…,xn​.

  9. If aM=M\mathfrak{a}M=MaM=M, a\mathfrak{a}a is nilpotent, then M=0M=0M=0.

  10. If N,N′⊂MN,N'\subset MN,N′⊂M, M=N+aN′M=N+\mathfrak{a}N'M=N+aN′, a\mathfrak{a}a is nilpotent, then M=NM=NM=N.

  11. Let f:N→Mf:N\to Mf:N→M be a homomorphism, fˉ:N/aN→M/aM\bar{f}:N /\mathfrak{a}N\to M /\mathfrak{a}Mfˉ​:N/aN→M/aM is surjective. If a\mathfrak{a}a is nilpotent, then fff is surjective.

  12. If {xα}α∈A\{x_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha\in A}{xα​}α∈A​ is a set of elements in MMM which generates M/aMM /\mathfrak{a}MM/aM and a\mathfrak{a}a is nilpotent, then MMM is generated by {xα}α∈A\{x_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha\in A}{xα​}α∈A​.

Proof

Proof.

  1. Choose y1,…,ymy_{1},\dots, y_{m}y1​,…,ym​ as generators of MMM. For each iii, we have yi=∑jzijyjy_{i}=\sum_{j}z_{ij}y_{j}yi​=∑j​zij​yj​ with zij∈az_{ij}\in \mathfrak{a}zij​∈a. Thus ∑j(δij−zij)yj=0\sum_{j}(\delta_{ij}-z_{ij})y_{j}=0∑j​(δij​−zij​)yj​=0. Let xxx be the determinant of m×mm\times mm×m matrix A=(δij−zij)A=(\delta_{ij}-z_{ij})A=(δij​−zij​). Note that x−1∈ax-1\in \mathfrak{a}x−1∈a. It’s easy to see A(y1⋮ym)=0A\begin{pmatrix} y_{1}\\\vdots\\ y_{m} \end{pmatrix}=0A⎝⎜⎜⎛​y1​⋮ym​​⎠⎟⎟⎞​=0. Let BBB be the adjoint matrix of AAA, BA(y1⋮ym)=(xy1⋮xym)=0BA\begin{pmatrix} y_{1}\\\vdots\\ y_{m} \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} xy_{1}\\\vdots\\ xy_{m} \end{pmatrix}=0BA⎝⎜⎜⎛​y1​⋮ym​​⎠⎟⎟⎞​=⎝⎜⎜⎛​xy1​⋮xym​​⎠⎟⎟⎞​=0, so xyi=0xy_{i}=0xyi​=0, xM=0xM=0xM=0.

  2. By 1, there’s x∈Rx\in Rx∈R, x−1∈ax-1\in\mathfrak{a}x−1∈a s.t. xM=0xM=0xM=0. Since x−1∈Rx-1\in \mathfrak{R}x−1∈R, 1+(x−1)1+(x-1)1+(x−1) is a unit, there’s x−1∈Rx^{-1}\in Rx−1∈R. Thus M=x−1xM=x−10=0M=x^{-1}xM=x^{-1}0=0M=x−1xM=x−10=0.

  3. If N′N'N′ is a finite generated module, then M/N=aN′/NM /N=\mathfrak{a}N' /NM/N=aN′/N is also finite generated. M/N=a(N′/N)⊂a(M/N)⊂M/NM /N=\mathfrak{a}(N' /N)\subset\mathfrak{a}(M /N)\subset M /NM/N=a(N′/N)⊂a(M/N)⊂M/N, so a(M/N)=M/N\mathfrak{a}(M /N)=M /Na(M/N)=M/N. Applying 1, there’s x∈Rx\in Rx∈R, x−1∈ax-1\in \mathfrak{a}x−1∈a s.t. x(M/N)=0x(M /N)=0x(M/N)=0. Thus xM⊂NxM\subset NxM⊂N and Mx⊂NxM_{x}\subset N_{x}Mx​⊂Nx​. Since N⊂MN\subset MN⊂M, Nx⊂MxN_{x}\subset M_{x}Nx​⊂Mx​. So Mx=NxM_{x}=N_{x}Mx​=Nx​.

  4. Applying 2 to finite generated module M/NM/NM/N, we have M/N=0M /N=0M/N=0, i.e. M=NM=NM=N.

  5. Since fˉ:N/aN→M/aM\bar{f}:N /\mathfrak{a}N\to M /\mathfrak{a}Mfˉ​:N/aN→M/aM is surjective, M=Imf+aMM=\mathrm{Im}f+\mathfrak{a}MM=Imf+aM. Applying 3 to finite generated MMM, we have x∈Rx\in Rx∈R, x−1∈ax-1\in\mathfrak{a}x−1∈a and xM⊂ImfxM\subset\mathrm{Im}fxM⊂Imf, i.e. fx:Nx→Mxf_{x}:N_{x}\to M_{x}fx​:Nx​→Mx​ is surjective.

  6. Similarly, M=Imf+aMM=\mathrm{Im}f+\mathfrak{a}MM=Imf+aM. Applying 4 to finite generated MMM, we have M=ImfM=\mathrm{Im}fM=Imf, i.e. fff is surjective.

  7. Take f:Rn→Mf:R^{n}\to Mf:Rn→M given by f:(a1,⋯ ,an)↦a1x1+⋯+anxnf:(a_{1},\cdots, a_{n})\mapsto a_{1}x_{1}+\cdots+a_{n}x_{n}f:(a1​,⋯,an​)↦a1​x1​+⋯+an​xn​. fˉ:Rn/aRn→M/aM\bar{f}:R^{n} /\mathfrak{a}R^{n}\to M /\mathfrak{a}Mfˉ​:Rn/aRn→M/aM given by fˉ:(a1ˉ,⋯ ,anˉ)↦a1ˉx1+⋯+anˉxn\bar{f}:(\bar{a_{1}},\cdots, \bar{a_{n}})\mapsto \bar{a_{1}}x_{1}+\cdots+ \bar{a_{n}}x_{n}fˉ​:(a1​ˉ​,⋯,an​ˉ​)↦a1​ˉ​x1​+⋯+an​ˉ​xn​ is obviously surjective. Applying 5, there is x∈Rx\in Rx∈R, x−1∈ax-1\in\mathfrak{a}x−1∈a s.t. fx:Rxn→Mxf_{x}:R_{x}^{n}\to M_{x}fx​:Rxn​→Mx​ surjective. Thus x1,…,xnx_{1},\dots, x_{n}x1​,…,xn​ generates MxM_{x}Mx​ over RxR_{x}Rx​.

  8. Take f:Rn→Mf:R^{n}\to Mf:Rn→M given by f:(a1,⋯ ,an)↦a1x1+⋯+anxnf:(a_{1},\cdots, a_{n})\mapsto a_{1}x_{1}+\cdots+a_{n}x_{n}f:(a1​,⋯,an​)↦a1​x1​+⋯+an​xn​. fˉ:Rn/aRn→M/aM\bar{f}:R^{n} /\mathfrak{a}R^{n}\to M /\mathfrak{a}Mfˉ​:Rn/aRn→M/aM given by fˉ:(a1ˉ,⋯ ,anˉ)↦a1ˉx1+⋯+anˉxn\bar{f}:(\bar{a_{1}},\cdots, \bar{a_{n}})\mapsto \bar{a_{1}}x_{1}+\cdots+ \bar{a_{n}}x_{n}fˉ​:(a1​ˉ​,⋯,an​ˉ​)↦a1​ˉ​x1​+⋯+an​ˉ​xn​ is obviously surjective. Applying 6, we obtain the surjectivity of fff. Thus x1,…,xnx_{1},\dots, x_{n}x1​,…,xn​ generates MMM.

  9. M=aMM=\mathfrak{a}MM=aM so M=anMM=\mathfrak{a}^{n}MM=anM for all n≥0n\geq 0n≥0. Assume an=0\mathfrak{a}^{n}=0an=0, then M=0M=0M=0M=0M=0M=0.

  10. Similar argument as above, we have a(M/N)=M/N\mathfrak{a}(M /N)=M /Na(M/N)=M/N. Applying 9, we have M/N=0M /N=0M/N=0, i.e. M=NM=NM=N.

  11. Similar as above argument, we have M=Imf+aMM=\mathrm{Im}f+\mathfrak{a}MM=Imf+aM. Applying 10, we have M=ImfM=\mathrm{Im}fM=Imf, i.e. fff is surjective.

  12. Take f:RA→Mf:R^{A}\to Mf:RA→M given by f:(aα)α∈A↦∑α∈Aaαxαf:(a_{\alpha})_{\alpha\in A}\mapsto \sum_{\alpha\in A}a_{\alpha}x_{\alpha}f:(aα​)α∈A​↦∑α∈A​aα​xα​. Then fˉ:RA/aRA→M/aM\bar{f}:R^{A} /\mathfrak{a}R^{A}\to M /\mathfrak{a}Mfˉ​:RA/aRA→M/aM is surjective. Applying 11, we have fff surjective. Thus MMM is generated by {xα}α∈A\{x_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha\in A}{xα​}α∈A​. ◻

entry.title: Absolutely Flatness (not finished)
entry.content:
啥都能水系列

Absolutely flatness 是使得任意module flat 的环, 并没有找到很多的absolutely flat 环, 常见的例子还是有field 和Boolean ring. Absolutely flatness 最大的特征是对任意极大理想局部化后是一个field. 同时absolutely flatness 和Zariski topology 的分离性有很强的关系.

Absolutely Flatness

Definition 1. A ring RRR is absolutely flat if every RRR-module is flat.

Now we give some property and criterion of absolutely flatness.

Theorem 1. For a ring RRR, the followings are equivalent:

1. RRR is absolutely flat.

2. Every finite generated ideal is direct summand of RRR.

3. Every finite generated ideal is idempotent.

4. Every principal ideal is idempotent.

Proof

Proof. 2 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 3: We have R≅a⊕R/aR\cong \mathfrak{a}\oplus R /\mathfrak{a}R≅a⊕R/a, so R/aR /\mathfrak{a}R/a is projective thus flat. Tensor 0→a→R→R/a→00\to \mathfrak{a}\to R\to R /\mathfrak{a}\to 00→a→R→R/a→0 with R/aR/\mathfrak{a}R/a, we will have 0→R/a⊗a→R/a⊗R→R/a⊗R/a→00\to R /\mathfrak{a}\otimes \mathfrak{a}\to R /\mathfrak{a}\otimes R\to R /\mathfrak{a}\otimes R /\mathfrak{a}\to 00→R/a⊗a→R/a⊗R→R/a⊗R/a→0. exact. Since R/a⊗a→R/a⊗RR /\mathfrak{a}\otimes \mathfrak{a}\to R /\mathfrak{a}\otimes RR/a⊗a→R/a⊗R is obviously zero morphism, it’s also injective so R/a⊗a≅a/a2=0R /\mathfrak{a}\otimes\mathfrak{a}\cong \mathfrak{a} /\mathfrak{a}^{2}=0R/a⊗a≅a/a2=0. Thus a\mathfrak{a}a is idempotent.

3 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 2: Let a\mathfrak{a}a be a finite generated ideal. By Nakayama lemma, there’s x∈ax\in \mathfrak{a}x∈a s.t. (1−x)a=0(1-x)\mathfrak{a}=0(1−x)a=0. Thus xa=axa=axa=a for all a∈aa\in \mathfrak{a}a∈a. So xxx generates a\mathfrak{a}a and x2=xx^{2}=xx2=x. So (x)∩(1−x)=0⇒R≅(x)⊕(1−x)(x)\cap (1-x)=0\Rightarrow R\cong (x)\oplus (1-x)(x)∩(1−x)=0⇒R≅(x)⊕(1−x).

1 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 3: Notice that R/aR /\mathfrak{a}R/a is flat and apply similar argument as 2 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 3.

3 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 4 is clear.

4 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 3: Let a=(a1,…,an)\mathfrak{a}=(a_{1},\dots, a_{n})a=(a1​,…,an​). Then each (ai)(a_{i})(ai​) are idempotent. So ai=xiai2a_{i}=x_{i}a_{i}^{2}ai​=xi​ai2​ for each iii. Thus a=a2\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{a}^{2}a=a2.

2 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 1: For any finite generated ideal a\mathfrak{a}a and an RRR-module MMM. R=a⊕R/aR=\mathfrak{a}\oplus R/\mathfrak{a}R=a⊕R/a so R/aR /\mathfrak{a}R/a is projective and thus flat. Consider the exact sequence 0→a→R→R/a→00\to \mathfrak{a}\to R\to R /\mathfrak{a}\to 00→a→R→R/a→0, the sequence 0→a⊗M→R⊗M→R/a⊗M→00\to \mathfrak{a}\otimes M\to R\otimes M\to R /\mathfrak{a}\otimes M\to 00→a⊗M→R⊗M→R/a⊗M→0 is exact. So 0→a⊗M→R⊗M→M/aM→00\to \mathfrak{a}\otimes M\to R\otimes M\to M /\mathfrak{a}M \to 00→a⊗M→R⊗M→M/aM→0 is exact. Thus aM≅a⊗M\mathfrak{a}M\cong \mathfrak{a}\otimes MaM≅a⊗M, MMM is flat. ◻

Theorem 2. RRR is absolutely flat and a\mathfrak{a}a is any ideal of RRR, then R/aR /\mathfrak{a}R/a is absolutely flat.

Proof

Proof. Take any principal ideal (xˉ)(\bar{x})(xˉ) of R/aR /\mathfrak{a}R/a. Then π−1((xˉ))=(x)\pi^{-1}((\bar{x}))=(x)π−1((xˉ))=(x) is also a principal ideal. So (x)(x)(x) is idempotent. Thus (xˉ)(\bar{x})(xˉ) is idempotent. ◻

Theorem 3. For RRR an absolutely flat ring, x∈Rx\in Rx∈R is not a unit, then xxx is a zero divisor.

Proof

Proof. (x)(x)(x) is idempotent so ax2=xax^{2}=xax2=x for some a∈Ra\in Ra∈R. So x(1−ax)=0x(1-ax)=0x(1−ax)=0, xxx is not a unit, 1−ax≠01-ax\neq 01−ax=0. Thus xxx is a zero divisor. ◻

Theorem 4. For RRR local absolutely flat ring. Then RRR is a field.

Proof

Proof. Take x∈Rx\in Rx∈R be a nonunit, x∈mx\in \mathfrak{m}x∈m the maximal ideal of RRR. (x)(x)(x) is idempotent so ax2=xax^{2}=xax2=x for some a∈Ra\in Ra∈R. xxx is in the Jacobson radical, so 1−ax1-ax1−ax is a unit, thus x=0x=0x=0. ◻

Theorem 5. Let RRR be a ring and SSS is a multiplicative subset, RRR is absolutely flat, then S−1RS^{-1}RS−1R is absolutely flat.

Theorem 6. RRR is absolutely flat if and only if RmR_{\mathfrak{m}}Rm​ is a field for any maximal ideal m\mathfrak{m}m of RRR.

Absolutely flatness has close relationship with the contructible topology, the Zariski topology and the constructible topology on the Spec(R)Spec(R)Spec(R) are the same if and only if R/NR/\mathfrak{N}R/N is absolutely flat.

Theorem 7. Let RRR be a ring, the followings are equivalent:

1. Let N\mathfrak{N}N be the nilradical of RRR, then R/NR /\mathfrak{N}R/N is absolutely flat.

2. Every prime ideal of RRR is a maximal ideal.

3. Spec(R)Spec(R)Spec(R) is T1T_{1}T1​ space.

4. Spec(R)Spec(R)Spec(R) is Hausdorff.
