entry.title: Faithfully Flat
entry.content:
Faithfully flat module 简单理解就是将tensor 前的序列的正合性等价于tensor 后序列的正合性. 比较好的判别法有: tensor非零module 后依旧非零. 在代数几何里面faithfully flatness 可以用来构造平坦下降~~(虽然我不会)~~

Faithfully Flatness

Definition 1. An RRR-module MMM is faithfully flat if M⊗−M\otimes -M⊗− is exact and faithful.

Lemma 1. MMM is faithfully flat if and only if 0→N′→N→N′′→00\to N'\to N\to N''\to 00→N′→N→N′′→0 exact ⇔0→N′⊗M→N⊗M→N′′⊗M→0\Leftrightarrow 0\to N'\otimes M\to N\otimes M\to N''\otimes M\to 0⇔0→N′⊗M→N⊗M→N′′⊗M→0 exact.

Proof

Proof. If MMM is faithfully flat. Then 0→N′→N→N′′→00\to N'\to N\to N''\to 00→N′→N→N′′→0 exact implies ⇔0→N′⊗M→N⊗M→N′′⊗M→0\Leftrightarrow 0\to N'\otimes M\to N\otimes M\to N''\otimes M\to 0⇔0→N′⊗M→N⊗M→N′′⊗M→0 exact.

Consider $ 0\to N’\otimes M\xrightarrow{\bar{f}} N\otimes M\xrightarrow{\bar{g}} N’'\otimes M\to 0$,
there are f:N′→Nf:N'\to Nf:N′→N and g:N→N′′g:N\to N''g:N→N′′ s.t. f⊗idM=fˉf\otimes id_{M}=\bar{f}f⊗idM​=fˉ​, g⊗idM=gˉg\otimes id_{M}=\bar{g}g⊗idM​=gˉ​. Since functor −⊗M-\otimes M−⊗M commutes with composition, fff injective and ggg surjective, g∘f=0g\circ f=0g∘f=0. So 0→N′→fN→gN′′→00\to N'\xrightarrow{f}N\xrightarrow{g}N''\to 00→N′f​Ng​N′′→0 is exact.

Conversely, we can immediately have MMM flat. We only need to show 0Hom(N′⊗M,N⊗M)=f⊗M0_{\mathrm{Hom}(N'\otimes M, N\otimes M)}=f\otimes M0Hom(N′⊗M,N⊗M)​=f⊗M implies f=0Hom(N′,N)f=0_{\mathrm{Hom}(N',N)}f=0Hom(N′,N)​.

Since

0→Kerf→N′→N′→00\to \mathrm{Ker}f\to N'\to N'\to 00→Kerf→N′→N′→0

exact, by flatness,

0→Kerf⊗M→N′⊗M→N⊗M→00\to \mathrm{Ker}f\otimes M\to N'\otimes M\to N\otimes M\to 00→Kerf⊗M→N′⊗M→N⊗M→0

exact. Thus Kerf⊗M≅N′⊗M\mathrm{Ker}f\otimes M\cong N'\otimes MKerf⊗M≅N′⊗M. Let i:Kerf→N′i:\mathrm{Ker}f\to N'i:Kerf→N′ be the inclusion map, then 0→Kerf⊗M→i⊗MCokeri⊗M→00\to \mathrm{Ker}f\otimes M\xrightarrow{i\otimes M} \mathrm{Coker}i\otimes M\to 00→Kerf⊗Mi⊗M​Cokeri⊗M→0 is exact. Since tensor preserves cokernels, Cokeri⊗M=Coker(i⊗M)=0⇒Cokeri=0\mathrm{Coker}i\otimes M=\mathrm{Coker}(i\otimes M)=0\Rightarrow \mathrm{Coker}i=0Cokeri⊗M=Coker(i⊗M)=0⇒Cokeri=0. So f=0Hom(N′,N)f=0_{\mathrm{Hom}(N',N)}f=0Hom(N′,N)​. ◻

Theorem 1. Let RRR be a ring and MMM is an RRR-module, the followings are equivalent.

1. MMM is faithfully flat.

2. MMM is flat, and for any RRR-module N≠0N\neq 0N=0, we have N⊗M≠0N\otimes M\neq 0N⊗M=0.

3. MMM is flat, for any maximal ideal m\mathfrak{m}m of RRR, mM≠M\mathfrak{m}M\neq MmM=M.

Proof

Proof. 1 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 2: Suppose N⊗M=0N\otimes M=0N⊗M=0, since 0→N⊗M→00\to N\otimes M\to 00→N⊗M→0 exact, 0→N→00\to N\to 00→N→0 exact. So N=0N=0N=0.

2 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 3: M/mM≅(A/m)⊗MM /\mathfrak{m}M\cong (A /\mathfrak{m})\otimes MM/mM≅(A/m)⊗M. Since A/m≠0A /\mathfrak{m}\neq 0A/m=0, M/mM≠0M /\mathfrak{m}M\neq 0M/mM=0.

3 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 2: Take x∈Nx\in Nx∈N, x≠0x\neq 0x=0. Then Rx≅R/Ann(x)Rx\cong R /Ann(x)Rx≅R/Ann(x). Let m\mathfrak{m}m be the maximal ideal containing Ann(x)Ann(x)Ann(x), then Ann(x)M⊂mM⊂MAnn(x)M\subset \mathfrak{m}M\subset MAnn(x)M⊂mM⊂M. Thus (R/Ann(x))⊗M≅M/Ann(x)M≠0(R /Ann(x))\otimes M\cong M /Ann(x) M\neq 0(R/Ann(x))⊗M≅M/Ann(x)M=0. Since MMM is flat, 0→(R/Ann(x))⊗M→N⊗M→00\to (R /Ann(x))\otimes M\to N\otimes M\to 00→(R/Ann(x))⊗M→N⊗M→0 is exact. Thus N⊗M≠0N\otimes M\neq 0N⊗M=0.

2 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 1: For any f⊗M=0Hom(N′⊗M,N⊗M)f\otimes M=0_{\mathrm{Hom}(N'\otimes M, N\otimes M)}f⊗M=0Hom(N′⊗M,N⊗M)​, we need to show f=0Hom(N′,N)f=0_{\mathrm{Hom}(N',N)}f=0Hom(N′,N)​. Take i:Kerf→N′i:\mathrm{Ker}f\to N'i:Kerf→N′ and apply similar arguments as lemma. ◻

Corollary 1. Let R,R′R, R'R,R′ be local rings, φ:R→R′\varphi:R\to R'φ:R→R′ be a local homomorphism. Let M≠0M\neq 0M=0 be a finite generated R′R'R′ module, then MMM is flat over RRR if and only if MMM is faithfully flat over RRR.

Proof

Proof. Let m,n\mathfrak{m}, \mathfrak{n}m,n be the maximal ideals of RRR and R′R'R′ respectively. Then φ(m)⊂n\varphi(\mathfrak{m})\subset\mathfrak{n}φ(m)⊂n by the definition of local homomorphism. Then mM⊂nM\mathfrak{m}M \subset\mathfrak{n}MmM⊂nM, by Nakayama lemma, nM≠M\mathfrak{n}M\neq MnM=M. Thus mM≠M\mathfrak{m}M\neq MmM=M. Then apply the previous theorem. ◻

Faithfully flat has the descent property:

Theorem 2. If R′R'R′ is an RRR algebra and if MMM is faithfully flat R′R'R′-module and also faithfully over RRR, then R′R'R′ is faithfully flat over RRR.

Proof

Proof. For any exact RRR-module sequence 0→N′→N→N′′→00\to N'\to N\to N''\to 00→N′→N→N′′→0. MMM is faithfully flat RRR-module, so the exactness above is equivalent to the exactness of 0→N′⊗RM→N⊗RM→N′′⊗RM→00\to N'\otimes_{R}M\to N\otimes_{R}M\to N''\otimes_{R}M\to 00→N′⊗R​M→N⊗R​M→N′′⊗R​M→0. Thus its equivalent to the exactness of 0→(N′⊗RR′)⊗R′M→(N⊗RR′)⊗R′M→(N′′⊗RR′)⊗R′M→00\to (N'\otimes_{R}R')\otimes_{R'} M\to (N\otimes_{R} R')\otimes_{R'}M\to (N''\otimes_{R}R')\otimes_{R'}M\to 00→(N′⊗R​R′)⊗R′​M→(N⊗R​R′)⊗R′​M→(N′′⊗R​R′)⊗R′​M→0. Since MMM is faithfully flat R′R'R′ module, the exactness is equivalent to the exactness of 0→N′⊗RR′→N⊗RR′→N′′⊗RR′→00\to N'\otimes_{R}R'\to N\otimes_{R}R'\to N''\otimes_{R}R'\to 00→N′⊗R​R′→N⊗R​R′→N′′⊗R​R′→0. Thus R′R'R′ is faithfully flat over RRR. ◻

Similarly, if we give the weaker condition: MMM is flat over R′R'R′ and faithfully flat over RRR, we can have R′R'R′ is flat over RRR.

For R′R'R′ be an RRR algebra, we have teh following theorem:

Theorem 3. The followings are equivalent:

1. R′R'R′ is faithfully flat over RRR.

2. For every RRR-module MMM, the map α:M→M⊗RR′\alpha:M\to M\otimes_{R}R'α:M→M⊗R​R′ given by α:m↦m⊗1R′\alpha:m\mapsto m\otimes 1_{R'}α:m↦m⊗1R′​ is injective.

3. Every ideal a\mathfrak{a}a of RRR satisfies aec=a\mathfrak{a}^{ec}=\mathfrak{a}aec=a or equivalently, (aR′)c=a(\mathfrak{a}R')^{c}=\mathfrak{a}(aR′)c=a.

4. Every prime ideal p\mathfrak{p}p is contraction of some prime ideal q\mathfrak{q}q of R′R'R′. This is equivalent to f∗:Spec(R′)→Spec(R)f^{*}:Spec(R')\to Spec(R)f∗:Spec(R′)→Spec(R) is surjective.

5. Every maximal ideal extend to a proper ideal, or equivalently, mR′≠R′\mathfrak{m}R'\neq R'mR′=R′.

6. Every nonzero RRR-module MMM extends to a nonzero module, i.e. M⊗RR′≠0M\otimes_{R}R'\neq 0M⊗R​R′=0.

Proof

Proof. 1 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 2: Consider the exact sequence

0→Kerα⊗RR′→M⊗RR′→α⊗RidR′M⊗RR′⊗RR′0\to \mathrm{Ker}\alpha\otimes_{R}R'\to M\otimes_{R}R'\xrightarrow{\alpha\otimes_{R}id_{R'}}M\otimes_{R}R'\otimes_{R}R'0→Kerα⊗R​R′→M⊗R​R′α⊗R​idR′​​M⊗R​R′⊗R​R′

α⊗idR′:m⊗x⊗y↦m⊗xy\alpha\otimes id_{R'}:m\otimes x\otimes y\mapsto m\otimes xyα⊗idR′​:m⊗x⊗y↦m⊗xy is injective, so Ker(α⊗RidR′)=Kerα⊗RR′=0\mathrm{Ker}(\alpha\otimes_{R} id_{R'})=\mathrm{Ker}\alpha\otimes_{R}R'=0Ker(α⊗R​idR′​)=Kerα⊗R​R′=0. Thus Kerα=0\mathrm{Ker}\alpha=0Kerα=0, α\alphaα is injective.

2 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 3: By assumption, R/a→R/a⊗R′=R′/aR′R /\mathfrak{a}\to R /\mathfrak{a}\otimes R'=R' /\mathfrak{a}R'R/a→R/a⊗R′=R′/aR′ is injective. aR=ae\mathfrak{a}R=\mathfrak{a}^{e}aR=ae. So ∀x∈ae\forall x\in \mathfrak{a}^{e}∀x∈ae, there is y∈ay\in \mathfrak{a}y∈a s.t. f(y)=xf(y)=xf(y)=x where f:R→R′f:R\to R'f:R→R′. So f−1(x)∈af^{-1}(x)\in\mathfrak{a}f−1(x)∈a, aec⊂a\mathfrak{a}^{ec}\subset\mathfrak{a}aec⊂a,
aec=a\mathfrak{a}^{ec}=\mathfrak{a}aec=a.

3 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 4: Take S=f(R−p)S=f(R-\mathfrak{p})S=f(R−p), then SSS is multiplicative closed. pe∩S=∅\mathfrak{p}^{e}\cap S=\varnothingpe∩S=∅ since pec=p\mathfrak{p}^{ec}=\mathfrak{p}pec=p. Take Σ={b∣b⊃pe,b∩S=∅}\Sigma=\{\mathfrak{b}|\mathfrak{b}\supset \mathfrak{p}^{e}, \mathfrak{b}\cap S=\varnothing\}Σ={b∣b⊃pe,b∩S=∅}. By Zorn’s lemma, Σ\SigmaΣ has a maximal element q\mathfrak{q}q. It’s easy to show q\mathfrak{q}q is prime. f−1(q)⊃pf^{-1}(\mathfrak{q})\supset \mathfrak{p}f−1(q)⊃p, f−1(q)∩(R−p)=∅f^{-1}(\mathfrak{q})\cap (R-\mathfrak{p})=\varnothingf−1(q)∩(R−p)=∅, then qc=p\mathfrak{q}^{c}=pqc=p.

4 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 5: m=qc\mathfrak{m}=\mathfrak{q}^{c}m=qc for some prime q\mathfrak{q}q in R′R'R′, then mR′⊂q≠R\mathfrak{m}R'\subset\mathfrak{q}\neq RmR′⊂q=R.

5 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 6: Take m∈M,m≠0m\in M, m\neq 0m∈M,m=0. Let M′=RmM'=RmM′=Rm, thus i:M′→Mi:M'\to Mi:M′→M will give injective i⊗idR′:M′⊗R′→M⊗R′i\otimes id_{R'}:M'\otimes R'\to M\otimes R'i⊗idR′​:M′⊗R′→M⊗R′. If M⊗R′=0M\otimes R'=0M⊗R′=0, we have M′⊗R′=0M'\otimes R'=0M′⊗R′=0. Since M′≅R/Ann(m)M'\cong R /Ann(m)M′≅R/Ann(m), we have R′/Ann(m)R′=0R' /Ann(m)R'=0R′/Ann(m)R′=0. Take m\mathfrak{m}m be the a maximal ideal containing Ann(m)Ann(m)Ann(m), then Ann(m)R′⊂mR′⊊R′Ann(m)R'\subset \mathfrak{m}R'\subsetneq R'Ann(m)R′⊂mR′⊊R′. Contradiction!

6 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 1: Already done. ◻
entry.summary: Faithfully flat module 简单理解就是将tensor 前的序列的正合性等价于tensor 后序列的正合性. 比较好的判别法有: tensor非零module 后依旧非零. 在代数几何里面faithfully flatness 可以用来构造平坦下降~~(虽然我不会)~~

entry.title: Flat Module
entry.content:
Flat module 的第一部分内容, 主要是一部分的判别法. Flatness的性质确实十分多, 并且也没有injective 和projective 那么直观. Atiyah 中还有一个很重要的结果是colimit 会保持exact sequence, 并且colimit 可以和Tor进行交换. 这只是flatness 很小的一部分东西.

Flat Module

Definition 1. An RRR-module MMM is flat if M⊗R−M\otimes_{R} -M⊗R​− is exact. Moreover, if the functor is faithful, we call MMM faithfully flat.

Flatness can be preserved by the direct sum.

Lemma 1. A direct sum M=⨁MλM=\bigoplus M_{\lambda}M=⨁Mλ​ is flat if and only if MλM_{\lambda}Mλ​ is flat for every λ\lambdaλ. Further, MMM is faithfully flat if at least on MλM_{\lambda}Mλ​ is faithfully flat.

Proof

Proof. For f:N′→Nf:N'\to Nf:N′→N an injective homomorphism, (⨁Mλ)⊗f=⨁(Mλ⊗f)(\bigoplus M_{\lambda})\otimes f= \bigoplus(M_{\lambda}\otimes f)(⨁Mλ​)⊗f=⨁(Mλ​⊗f). Here ⨁(Mλ⊗f):M⊗N′→M⊗N\bigoplus(M_{\lambda}\otimes f): M\otimes N'\to M\otimes N⨁(Mλ​⊗f):M⊗N′→M⊗N is injective. Thus M⊗−M\otimes -M⊗− preserves injectives if and only if MλM_{\lambda}Mλ​ preserves injectives.

For faithfully flat, M⊗N=⨁((Mλ⊗N))M\otimes N=\bigoplus ((M_{\lambda}\otimes N))M⊗N=⨁((Mλ​⊗N)). Thus if M⊗N=0M\otimes N=0M⊗N=0, then Mλ⊗N=0M_{\lambda}\otimes N=0Mλ​⊗N=0 for all λ\lambdaλ. If at least one MλM_{\lambda}Mλ​ is faithfully flat, then immediately N=0N=0N=0. MMM is faithfully flat. ◻

Theorem 1. A nonzero free module is faithfully flat. Projective modules are flat.

Proof

Proof. For free module F≅⨁ΛRF\cong \bigoplus_{\Lambda} RF≅⨁Λ​R. RRR is obviously faithfully flat, so FFF is faithfully flat. Since projective modules are direct summands of free modules, they are flat. ◻

Proposition 1. For 0→M′→M→M′′→00\to M'\to M\to M''\to 00→M′→M→M′′→0 an exact sequence of modules. Assume M′′M''M′′ is flat.

1. 0→M′⊗N→M⊗N→M′′⊗N→00\to M'\otimes N\to M\otimes N\to M''\otimes N\to 00→M′⊗N→M⊗N→M′′⊗N→0 is exact for any module NNN.

2. MMM is flat if and only if M′M'M′ is flat.

Proof

Proof.

  1. For any NNN, take the free presentation 0→K→RΛ→N→00\to K\to R^{\Lambda}\to N\to 00→K→RΛ→N→0, tensor it with the exact sequence 0→M′→M→M′′→00\to M'\to M\to M''\to 00→M′→M→M′′→0, we have the following commutative diagram.

Since RΛR^{\Lambda}RΛ and M′′M''M′′ are flat, α\alphaα and β\betaβ are injective. So each rows and columns are exact. Then just apply the snake lemma. 0→M′⊗N→γM⊗N0\to M'\otimes N\xrightarrow{\gamma} M\otimes N0→M′⊗Nγ​M⊗N is exact. γ\gammaγ is injective so 0→M′⊗N→M⊗N→M′′⊗N→00\to M'\otimes N\to M\otimes N\to M''\otimes N\to 00→M′⊗N→M⊗N→M′′⊗N→0 is exact.

  1. Assume f:N′→Nf:N'\to Nf:N′→N be an injective homomorphism, consider the diagram:

each rows are exact.

Assume MMM is flat, then α\alphaα is injective, M′M'M′ is flat.

Assume M′M'M′ is flat, then α′\alpha'α′ is injective. By five lemma, α\alphaα is injective, MMM is flat. ◻

Criterion of Flatness

Now we give some criterion of flatness.

Theorem 2. If every finitely generated submodule of MMM is flat, then M is flat.

Proof

Proof. For injective f:A→Bf:A\to Bf:A→B, we only need to show idM⊗f:M⊗A→M⊗Bid_{M}\otimes f:M\otimes A\to M\otimes BidM​⊗f:M⊗A→M⊗B is injective. For any u∈KeridM⊗fu\in\mathrm{Ker}id_{M}\otimes fu∈KeridM​⊗f, we construct finite generated submodule NNN of MMM and v∈Nv\in Nv∈N s.t. i⊗idA(v)=ui\otimes id_{A}(v)=ui⊗idA​(v)=u, iii is the inclusion map. Assume u=∑i=1nmi⊗aiu=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}m_{i}\otimes a_{i}u=i=1∑n​mi​⊗ai​, (idM⊗f)(u)=∑i=1nmi⊗f(ai)(id_{M}\otimes f)(u)=\sum_{i=1}^{n}m_{i}\otimes f(a_{i})(idM​⊗f)(u)=∑i=1n​mi​⊗f(ai​). Let (idM⊗f)(u)(id_{M}\otimes f)(u)(idM​⊗f)(u) be finite linear combination of elements in M×BM\times BM×B, and take all the elements of the MMM-coordinate to form the set SSS. Let NNN be the submodule of MMM generated by S∪{m1,…,mn}S\cup\{m_{1},\dots,m_{n}\}S∪{m1​,…,mn​}, v=∑i=1nmi⊗ai∈N⊗Av=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}m_{i}\otimes a_{i}\in N\otimes Av=i=1∑n​mi​⊗ai​∈N⊗A, then the conditions are satisfied. ◻

Similarly, we can proof the criterion.

Theorem 3. MMM is flat if and only if idM⊗f:M⊗N′→M⊗Nid_{M}\otimes f: M\otimes N'\to M\otimes NidM​⊗f:M⊗N′→M⊗N is injective for any f:N′→Nf:N'\to Nf:N′→N injective homomorphism, N′,NN', NN′,N are finitely generated.

Proof

Proof. Omitted. ◻

Theorem 4 (Lazard). MMM is flat if and only if MMM is the colimit of direct system of free finite modules.

Proof

Proof. Omiited. ◻

Theorem 5. For an RRR-module MMM, and if ∑ixiyi=0\sum_{i}x_{i}y_{i}=0∑i​xi​yi​=0 with xi∈Rx_{i}\in Rxi​∈R, yi∈My_{i}\in Myi​∈M implies there are xij∈Rx_{ij}\in Rxij​∈R, yj′∈My_{j}'\in Myj′​∈M s.t. ∑jxijyj′=yj\sum_{j}x_{ij}y_{j}'=y_{j}∑j​xij​yj′​=yj​ for all iii, any ∑ixijxi=0\sum_{i}x_{ij}x_{i}=0∑i​xij​xi​=0 for all kkk. Then MMM is flat.

Proof

Proof. Only need to show for any given α:Rm→M\alpha:R^{m}\to Mα:Rm→M and k∈Kerαk\in\mathrm{Ker}\alphak∈Kerα, there is φ:Rm→Rn\varphi:R^{m}\to R^{n}φ:Rm→Rn s.t. α:Rm→φRn→M\alpha:R^{m}\xrightarrow{\varphi}R^{n}\to Mα:Rmφ​Rn→M with φ(k)=0\varphi(k)=0φ(k)=0. Then MMM is filtered direct colimit of free modules with finite rank, by Lazard theorem, MMM is flat.

Let k=∑ixieik=\sum_{i}x_{i}e_{i}k=∑i​xi​ei​ {ei}\{e_{i}\}{ei​} is the basis of RmR^{m}Rm. Define φ:Rm→Rn\varphi:R^{m}\to R^{n}φ:Rm→Rn from the matrix (xij)(x_{ij})(xij​), then φ(k)=∑iφ(ei)=∑ixi∑jxijej′\varphi(k)=\sum_{i}\varphi(e_{i})=\sum_{i}x_{i}\sum_{j}x_{ij}e_{j}'φ(k)=∑i​φ(ei​)=∑i​xi​∑j​xij​ej′​, {ej′}\{e_{j}'\}{ej′​} is the basis of RnR^{n}Rn. Then φ(k)=0\varphi(k)=0φ(k)=0 by assumption. Define β:Rn→M\beta:R^{n}\to Mβ:Rn→M by β(ej′)=yj′\beta(e_{j}')=y_{j}'β(ej′​)=yj′​. Then β(φ(ej))=β(∑ixijej)=∑ixijyj′=yj\beta(\varphi(e_{j}))=\beta(\sum_{i} x_{ij}e_{j})=\sum_{i}x_{ij}y_{j}'=y_{j}β(φ(ej​))=β(∑i​xij​ej​)=∑i​xij​yj′​=yj​. Thus βφ=α\beta\varphi=\alphaβφ=α. ◻

Actually, the result in the above theorem is an if and only if relation.

Lemma 2. Let RRR be a ring, MMM and NNN are RRR-modules, and {nλ}λ∈Λ\{n_{\lambda}\}_{\lambda\in\Lambda}{nλ​}λ∈Λ​ is a set of generators of NNN. Then any element of M⊗NM\otimes NM⊗N can be written as a finite sum ∑mλ⊗nλ\sum m_{\lambda}\otimes n_{\lambda}∑mλ​⊗nλ​ with mλ∈Mm_{\lambda}\in Mmλ​∈M. Further, ∑mλ⊗nλ=0\sum m_{\lambda}\otimes n_{\lambda}=0∑mλ​⊗nλ​=0 if and only if there are mσ∈Mm_{\sigma}\in Mmσ​∈M and xλσ∈Rx_{\lambda \sigma}\in Rxλσ​∈R for σ∈Σ\sigma\in \Sigmaσ∈Σ for some Σ\SigmaΣ s.t

∑σxλσmσ=mλ for all λ and ∑λxλσnλ=0 for all σ\sum_{\sigma}x_{\lambda \sigma}m_{\sigma}=m_{\lambda} \text{ for all }\lambda \text{ and } \sum_{\lambda}x_{\lambda \sigma}n_{\lambda}=0 \text{ for all }\sigmaσ∑​xλσ​mσ​=mλ​ for all λ and λ∑​xλσ​nλ​=0 for all σ

Proof

Proof. M⊗NM\otimes NM⊗N is generated by the elements of the form m⊗nm\otimes nm⊗n. If n=∑xλnλn=\sum x_{\lambda}n_{\lambda}n=∑xλ​nλ​ with xλ∈Rx_{\lambda}\in Rxλ​∈R, then m⊗n=∑(xλm)⊗nλm\otimes n=\sum(x_{\lambda}m)\otimes n_{\lambda}m⊗n=∑(xλ​m)⊗nλ​. Thus any element of M⊗NM\otimes NM⊗N has the form ∑mλ⊗nλ\sum m_{\lambda}\otimes n_{\lambda}∑mλ​⊗nλ​. Assume mσm_{\sigma}mσ​ and the xλσx_{\lambda \sigma}xλσ​ exist, then

∑mλ⊗nλ=∑λ(∑σxλσmσ)⊗nλ=∑σ(mσ⊗∑λxλσnλ)=0\sum m_{\lambda}\otimes n_{\lambda}=\sum_{\lambda}(\sum_{\sigma}x_{\lambda \sigma}m_{\sigma})\otimes n_{\lambda}=\sum_{\sigma}(m_{\sigma}\otimes \sum_{\lambda}x_{\lambda \sigma}n_{\lambda})=0∑mλ​⊗nλ​=λ∑​(σ∑​xλσ​mσ​)⊗nλ​=σ∑​(mσ​⊗λ∑​xλσ​nλ​)=0

Conversely, take a free presentation RΣ→βRΛ→αN→0R^{\Sigma}\xrightarrow{\beta}R^{\Lambda}\xrightarrow{\alpha}N\to 0RΣβ​RΛα​N→0 with α(eλ)=nλ\alpha(e_{\lambda})=n_{\lambda}α(eλ​)=nλ​ for all λ\lambdaλ, where {eλ}\{e_{\lambda}\}{eλ​} is the basis of RΛR^{\Lambda}RΛ. Then the sequence M⊗RΣ→M⊗RΛ→M⊗N→0M\otimes R^{\Sigma}\to M\otimes R^{\Lambda} \to M\otimes N\to 0M⊗RΣ→M⊗RΛ→M⊗N→0 is exact. idM⊗α(∑mλ⊗eλ)=0id_{M}\otimes \alpha(\sum m_{\lambda} \otimes e_{\lambda})=0idM​⊗α(∑mλ​⊗eλ​)=0, so the exactness implies there’s s∈M⊗RΣs\in M\otimes R^{\Sigma}s∈M⊗RΣ s.t. (1⊗β)(s)=∑mλ⊗eλ(1\otimes \beta)(s)=\sum m_{\lambda}\otimes e_{\lambda}(1⊗β)(s)=∑mλ​⊗eλ​. Let {eσ}\{e_{\sigma}\}{eσ​} be the basis of RΣR^{\Sigma}RΣ and s=∑mσ⊗eσs=\sum m_{\sigma}\otimes e_{\sigma}s=∑mσ​⊗eσ​ with mσ∈Mm_{\sigma}\in Mmσ​∈M. Write β(eσ)=∑λxλσeλ\beta(e_{\sigma})=\sum_{\lambda}x_{\lambda \sigma}e_{\lambda}β(eσ​)=∑λ​xλσ​eλ​. Then ∑λxλσnλ=α(β(eσ))=0\sum_{\lambda}x_{\lambda \sigma}n_{\lambda}=\alpha(\beta(e_{\sigma}))=0∑λ​xλσ​nλ​=α(β(eσ​))=0 and

0=∑λmλ⊗eλ−∑σmσ⊗(∑λxλσeλ)=∑λ(mλ−∑σxλσmσ)⊗eλ0=\sum_{\lambda}m_{\lambda}\otimes e_{\lambda}-\sum_{\sigma}m_{\sigma}\otimes(\sum_{\lambda}x_{\lambda\sigma}e_{\lambda})=\sum_{\lambda}(m_{\lambda}-\sum_{\sigma}x_{\lambda\sigma}m_{\sigma})\otimes e_{\lambda}0=λ∑​mλ​⊗eλ​−σ∑​mσ​⊗(λ∑​xλσ​eλ​)=λ∑​(mλ​−σ∑​xλσ​mσ​)⊗eλ​

Since eλe_{\lambda}eλ​ are independent, mλ=∑σxλσmσm_{\lambda}=\sum_{\sigma}x_{\lambda \sigma}m_{\sigma}mλ​=∑σ​xλσ​mσ​. ◻

Finally, we give the ideal criterion of flatness.

Theorem 6. An RRR-module NNN is flat if and only if for every finite generated ideal a\mathfrak{a}a, the natural map a⊗N→aN\mathfrak{a}\otimes N\to \mathfrak{a}Na⊗N→aN is an isomorphism.

Proof

Proof. Assume NNN is flat. We know R⊗N→NR\otimes N\to NR⊗N→N is an isomorphism, NNN is flat so injective homomorphism a→R\mathfrak{a}\to Ra→R induces a⊗N→R⊗N=N\mathfrak{a}\otimes N\to R\otimes N=Na⊗N→R⊗N=N. So a⊗N→aN\mathfrak{a}\otimes N\to \mathfrak{a}Na⊗N→aN is injective thus an isomorphism.

Conversely, given any ∑i=1nxiyi=0\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}y_{i}=0i=1∑n​xi​yi​=0 with xi∈Rx_{i}\in Rxi​∈R, yi∈Ny_{i}\in Nyi​∈N. Take a=(x1,…,xn)\mathfrak{a}=(x_{1},\dots, x_{n})a=(x1​,…,xn​). If a⊗N≅aN\mathfrak{a}\otimes N\cong \mathfrak{a}Na⊗N≅aN, then ∑ixi⊗yi=0\sum_{i}x_{i}\otimes y_{i}=0∑i​xi​⊗yi​=0, by lemma above, we have ∑σxλσmσ=mλ\sum_{\sigma}x_{\lambda \sigma}m_{\sigma}=m_{\lambda}∑σ​xλσ​mσ​=mλ​ for all λ\lambdaλ and ∑λxλσnλ=0\sum_{\lambda}x_{\lambda \sigma}n_{\lambda}=0∑λ​xλσ​nλ​=0 for all σ\sigmaσ. Thus NNN is flat. ◻

Theorem 7. Let RRR be a ring and MMM be a module. Then the following conditions are equivalent:

1. MMM is flat.

2. Given a finitely presented module PPP, then there is a canonical homomorphism θ:HomR(P,R)⊗RM→HomR(P,M)\theta: \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(P,R)\otimes_{R} M\to \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(P,M)θ:HomR​(P,R)⊗R​M→HomR​(P,M) and θ\thetaθ is surjective.

3. Given a finite presented module PPP and a map β:P→M\beta:P\to Mβ:P→M, there is a factorization β:P→γPn→αM\beta: P\xrightarrow{\gamma} P^{n}\xrightarrow{\alpha}Mβ:Pγ​Pnα​M.

4. Given an α:Rm→M\alpha:R^{m}\to Mα:Rm→M and a k∈Kerαk\in\mathrm{Ker}\alphak∈Kerα, there exists a factorization α:Rm→φRn→M\alpha: R^{m}\xrightarrow{\varphi}R^{n}\to Mα:Rmφ​Rn→M such that φ(k)=0\varphi(k)=0φ(k)=0.

5. Given an α:Rm→M\alpha:R^{m}\to Mα:Rm→M and k1,…,kr∈Kerαk_{1},\dots, k_{r}\in\mathrm{Ker}\alphak1​,…,kr​∈Kerα, there exists a factorization α:Rm→φRn→M\alpha:R^{m}\xrightarrow{\varphi}R^{n}\to Mα:Rmφ​Rn→M such that φ(ki)=0\varphi(k_{i})=0φ(ki​)=0 for i=1,…,ri=1,\dots, ri=1,…,r.

6. Given Rr→ρRm→αMR^{r}\xrightarrow{\rho}R^{m}\xrightarrow{\alpha}MRrρ​Rmα​M such that αρ=0\alpha \rho=0αρ=0, there exists a factorization α:Rm→φRn→M\alpha: R^{m}\xrightarrow{\varphi}R^{n}\to Mα:Rmφ​Rn→M such that φρ=0\varphi \rho=0φρ=0.

7. Let ΛM\Lambda_{M}ΛM​ be the category whose objects are the pairs (Rm,α)(R^{m},\alpha)(Rm,α), where α:Rm→M\alpha:R^{m}\to Mα:Rm→M is a homomorphism. The morphisms are the homomorphisms φ:Rm→Rn\varphi:R^{m}\to R^{n}φ:Rm→Rn with βφ=α\beta \varphi=\alphaβφ=α. Then ΛM\Lambda_{M}ΛM​ is filtered.

8. MMM is a filtered direct limit of free modules of finite rank.

Proof

Proof. Omitted. ◻
entry.summary: Flat module 的第一部分内容, 主要是一部分的判别法. Flatness的性质确实十分多, 并且也没有injective 和projective 那么直观. Atiyah 中还有一个很重要的结果是colimit 会保持exact sequence, 并且colimit 可以和Tor进行交换. 这只是flatness 很小的一部分东西.

entry.title: Injective Module
entry.content:
Injective 是projective 的对偶, 但是在问题的处理上却复杂得多. 核心原因是我们在处理projective module 时是去寻找一个打到它的满射, 而injective module 则是需要寻找一个从它出发的单射. Zorn引理在这里具有很强的效果. Baer 判别法也是一个很有效的工具.

Injective Module

Injective is the dual of projective.

Definition 1. An RRR-module III is injective if for any exact sequence 0→A→iB0\to A\xrightarrow{i} B0→Ai​B and f:A→If:A\to If:A→I, there exists an homomorphism g:B→Ig:B\to Ig:B→I s.t. f=g∘if=g\circ if=g∘i.

We have similar results as projective module.

Theorem 1. The functor Hom(−,I)\mathrm{Hom}(-,I)Hom(−,I) is exact if and only if III is injective.

Proof

Proof. Similar to the projective. Omitted. ◻

Lemma 1. For any family of injective modules {Mi}i∈I\{M_{i}\}_{i\in I}{Mi​}i∈I​, ∏i∈IMi\prod\limits_{i\in I}M_{i}i∈I∏​Mi​ is also injective.

Proof

Proof. For exact sequence 0→A→iB0\to A\xrightarrow{i}B0→Ai​B and f:A→∏i∈IMif:A\to \prod\limits_{i\in I} M_{i}f:A→i∈I∏​Mi​, we will have πi∘f:A→Mi\pi_{i}\circ f:A\to M_{i}πi​∘f:A→Mi​ the homomorphisms. Using the universal property of product, we have gi:B→Mig_{i}:B\to M_{i}gi​:B→Mi​ with gi∘i=πi∘fg_{i}\circ i=\pi_{i}\circ fgi​∘i=πi​∘f. ◻

Lemma 2. If M⊕NM\oplus NM⊕N is injective, the so are MMM and NNN.

Proof

Proof. Consider the diagram

with the bottom row exact, we have

Here j∘f:A→M⊕Nj\circ f:A \to M\oplus Nj∘f:A→M⊕N, and by injectivity of M⊕NM\oplus NM⊕N, we have g:B→M⊕Ng:B\to M\oplus Ng:B→M⊕N with g∘i=j∘fg\circ i=j\circ fg∘i=j∘f, so (π∘g)∘i=π∘(j∘f)=f(\pi\circ g)\circ i=\pi\circ (j\circ f)=f(π∘g)∘i=π∘(j∘f)=f. Thus MMM is injective. Similar for NNN. ◻

Now we give a very useful criterion for injective module:

Theorem 2. An RRR-module EEE is injective if and only if every homomorphism f:I→Ef:I\to Ef:I→E from an ideal III of RRR can be extended to the whole ring, i.e. ∃g:R→E\exists g:R\to E∃g:R→E, for g∣I=fg|_{I}=fg∣I​=f.

Proof

Proof. Assume EEE injective is clear.

Conversely, for any diagram

with the bottom row exact, we can regard MMM as the submodule of NNN, consider the set

Σ={(A,g)∣M⊆A⊆N,g:A→E,f can be extend to g}\Sigma=\{(A,g)|M\subseteq A\subseteq N, g:A\to E, f \text{ can be extend to g}\}Σ={(A,g)∣M⊆A⊆N,g:A→E,f can be extend to g}

Σ\SigmaΣ is obviously a nonempty partially ordered set. For any chain C⊂ΣC\subset \SigmaC⊂Σ, choose (⋃(Ai,gi)∈CAi,⋃(Ai,gi)∈Cgi)(\bigcup\limits_{(A_{i},g_{i})\in C}A_{i}, \bigcup\limits_{(A_{i},g_{i})\in C}g_{i})((Ai​,gi​)∈C⋃​Ai​,(Ai​,gi​)∈C⋃​gi​), here ⋃(Ai,gi)∈Cgi\bigcup\limits_{(A_{i},g_{i})\in C}g_{i}(Ai​,gi​)∈C⋃​gi​ means ∀a∈Ai\forall a\in A_{i}∀a∈Ai​, a↦gi(a)a\mapsto g_{i}(a)a↦gi​(a). Obviously, (⋃(Ai,gi)∈CAi,⋃(Ai,gi)∈Cgi)(\bigcup\limits_{(A_{i},g_{i})\in C}A_{i}, \bigcup\limits_{(A_{i},g_{i})\in C}g_{i})((Ai​,gi​)∈C⋃​Ai​,(Ai​,gi​)∈C⋃​gi​) is an upper bound of CCC. Thus Σ\SigmaΣ has a maximal element (A,g)(A,g)(A,g).

Now we show A=NA=NA=N. Suppose not ∃n∈N\exists n\in N∃n∈N, x∉Ax\notin Ax∈/A, take an ideal I={r∈R∣nr∈A}I=\{r\in R|nr\in A\}I={r∈R∣nr∈A} and h:I→Eh:I\to Eh:I→E with h:r→g(rn)h:r\to g(rn)h:r→g(rn). By assumption, we can extend hhh into k:R→Ek:R\to Ek:R→E, with k∣I=Ek|_{I}=Ek∣I​=E. Consider φ:A+Rn→E\varphi:A+Rn\to Eφ:A+Rn→E with φ:a+rn↦g(a)+g(rn)=g(a)+h(r)\varphi:a+rn\mapsto g(a)+g(rn)=g(a)+h(r)φ:a+rn↦g(a)+g(rn)=g(a)+h(r), then (A+Rn,φ)(A+Rn,\varphi)(A+Rn,φ) is a larger element than (A,g)(A,g)(A,g) in Σ\SigmaΣ. Contradiction! Thus N=AN=AN=A. ◻

Theorem 3. Let RRR be a Noetherian ring. If {Mj}j∈J\{M_{j}\}_{j\in J}{Mj​}j∈J​ is a family of injective modules, then ⨁j∈JMj\bigoplus\limits_{j\in J}M_{j}j∈J⨁​Mj​ is injective.

Proof

Proof. Only need to show for any ideal I⊂RI\subset RI⊂R, and f:I→⨁j∈JMjf:I\to \bigoplus\limits_{j\in J}M_{j}f:I→j∈J⨁​Mj​, it can be extended to RRR. Since RRR is Noetherian, III is finite generated. Assume I=(a1,…,an)I=(a_{1},\dots, a_{n})I=(a1​,…,an​), for i=1,…,ni=1,\dots, ni=1,…,n, f(ai)=(bi,j)j∈Jf(a_{i})=(b_{i,j})_{j\in J}f(ai​)=(bi,j​)j∈J​, where bi,j=0b_{i,j}=0bi,j​=0 for all but finite jjj. Then K={j∈J∣f(ai)j≠0 for some i=1,…,n}K=\{j\in J|f(a_{i})_{j}\neq 0 \text{ for some }i=1,\dots, n\}K={j∈J∣f(ai​)j​=0 for some i=1,…,n} is finite. f(I)⊂⨁j∈KMjf(I)\subset \bigoplus\limits_{j\in K}M_{j}f(I)⊂j∈K⨁​Mj​, ⨁j∈KMj\bigoplus\limits_{j\in K}M_{j}j∈K⨁​Mj​ and ∏j∈KMj\prod\limits_{j\in K}M_{j}j∈K∏​Mj​ agree with each other. So we have gˉ:R→⨁j∈KMj\bar{g}:R\to \bigoplus\limits_{j\in K}M_{j}gˉ​:R→j∈K⨁​Mj​, and thus g:R→⨁j∈JMjg:R\to \bigoplus\limits_{j\in J}M_{j}g:R→j∈J⨁​Mj​. ◻

However, for non Noetherian ring, the direct sum of injective module may not be injective. The theorem is actually if and only if. For any non Noetherian ring RRR, there is a strictly increasing chain of ideals: I1⊊I2⊊⋯I_{1}\subsetneq I_{2}\subsetneq\cdotsI1​⊊I2​⊊⋯. Let EiE_{i}Ei​ be the injective envelope of R/IiR /I_{i}R/Ii​, i.e. EiE_{i}Ei​ is injective, R/Ii⊂EiR /I_{i}\subset E_{i}R/Ii​⊂Ei​ and for any submodule NNN of EiE_{i}Ei​, R/Ii∩N≠∅R /I_{i}\cap N\neq \varnothingR/Ii​∩N=∅. Take E=⨁i=1nEiE=\bigoplus\limits_{i=1}^{n}E_{i}E=i=1⨁n​Ei​, EEE is not injective.

Divisible Module

Definition 2. An RRR-module DDD is divisible if for every r∈Rr\in Rr∈R and d∈Dd\in Dd∈D, ∃b∈D\exists b\in D∃b∈D s.t. rb=drb=drb=d.

For any integral domain RRR, the injective module EEE is always divisible: For any r∈Rr\in Rr∈R and d∈Dd\in Dd∈D, take f:(r)→Ef:(r)\to Ef:(r)→E with f:xr↦xdf:xr\mapsto xdf:xr↦xd. Then extend fff to g:R→Eg:R\to Eg:R→E, thus d=f(r)=rf(1)d=f(r)=rf(1)d=f(r)=rf(1), EEE is divisible.

The converse is not true in general. For the integral domain R[x,y]R[x,y]R[x,y] and QQQ is the field of fractions, then the RRR-module Q/RQ /RQ/R is divisible but not injective.

Theorem 4. Let RRR be a PID.

1. An RRR-module EEE is injective if and only if it is divisible.

2. Quotient module of injective module are injective.

Proof

Proof.

  1. Only need to show divisible modules are injective. Let EEE be a divisible module, consider any ideal I≠(0)I\neq (0)I=(0) with a map f:I→Ef:I\to Ef:I→E, then I=(a)I=(a)I=(a) for some a∈Ra\in Ra∈R. Since EEE is divisible, ∃e∈E\exists e\in E∃e∈E s.t. f(a)=aef(a)=aef(a)=ae. Now consider g:R→Eg:R\to Eg:R→E with g:r↦reg:r\mapsto reg:r↦re, ggg extend fff to RRR.

  2. It’s easy to show for the quotient module of divisible module is
    divisible. ◻

Lemma 3. For any injective abelian group DDD, HomZ(R,D)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbb{Z}}(R,D)HomZ​(R,D) is injective RRR-module.

Proof

Proof. Let E=HomZ(R,D)E=\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbb{Z}}(R,D)E=HomZ​(R,D), EEE is obviously an RRR-module. Only need to show HomZ(−,E)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbb{Z}}(-,E)HomZ​(−,E) is exact. HomZ(−,E)≅HomZ(−⊗R,D)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbb{Z}}(-,E)\cong \mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbb{Z}}(-\otimes R,D)HomZ​(−,E)≅HomZ​(−⊗R,D) by adjoint functors. Since for RRR-module MMM, M⊗R≅RM\otimes R\cong RM⊗R≅R, and HomZ(−,D)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbb{Z}}(-,D)HomZ​(−,D) is exact, thus HomZ(−,E)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbb{Z}}(-,E)HomZ​(−,E) is exact. ◻

Theorem 5. Every RRR-module MMM is a submodule of some injective RRR-module.

Proof

Proof. There’s a free abelian group FFF and π:F→M\pi:F\to Mπ:F→M surjective. Since F≅⨁i∈IZF\cong \bigoplus\limits_{i\in I}\mathbb{Z}F≅i∈I⨁​Z, FFF can be embedded into D≅⨁i∈IQD\cong \bigoplus\limits_{i\in I}\mathbb{Q}D≅i∈I⨁​Q, DDD is divisible group.

Take f:D→Mf:D\to Mf:D→M be the surjective group homomorphism and fˉ:HomZ(R,M)→HomZ(R,D)\bar{f}:\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbb{Z}}(R,M)\to \mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbb{Z}}(R,D)fˉ​:HomZ​(R,M)→HomZ​(R,D). Since every RRR-module homomorphism is group homomorphism, HomR(R,M)⊂HomZ(R,A)\mathrm{Hom}_{R}(R,M)\subset \mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbb{Z}}(R,A)HomR​(R,M)⊂HomZ​(R,A). Consider the homomorphism g:R→HomR(R,M)g:R\to \mathrm{Hom}_{R}(R,M)g:R→HomR​(R,M) with g(a):r↦rag(a):r\mapsto rag(a):r↦ra, then ggg is injective. Then R→gHomR(R,M)→HomZ(R,M)R\xrightarrow{g}\mathrm{Hom}_{R}(R,M)\to \mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbb{Z}}(R,M)Rg​HomR​(R,M)→HomZ​(R,M) is a way to embed RRR into divisible RRR-module HomZ(R,M)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbb{Z}}(R,M)HomZ​(R,M). ◻

Finally, we build the criterion of injective via splitting exact sequence.

Theorem 6. An RRR-module III is injective if and only if every short exact sequence

$$0\to I\to B\to C\to 0$$

splits.

Proof

Proof. Assume III is an injective module, consider any short exact sequence, for the diagram

by injectivity, ∃g:B→I\exists g:B\to I∃g:B→I s.t. g∘i=idIg\circ i=id_{I}g∘i=idI​.

Conversely, suppose every short exact sequence 0→I→B→C→00\to I\to B\to C\to 00→I→B→C→0 splits and consider the diagram

III can be embedded into some injective RRR-module EEE via j:I→Ej: I\to Ej:I→E.

0→I→jE→Cokerj→00\to I\xrightarrow{j}E\to \mathrm{Coker}j\to 00→Ij​E→Cokerj→0

splits so ∃q:E→I\exists q:E\to I∃q:E→I s.t. q∘i=idIq\circ i=id_{I}q∘i=idI​.

The there exists l:B→El:B\to El:B→E s.t. l∘i=j∘fl\circ i=j\circ fl∘i=j∘f

Then q∘l∘i=q∘j∘f=fq\circ l\circ i=q\circ j\circ f=fq∘l∘i=q∘j∘f=f. Thus III is injective. ◻
entry.summary: Injective 是projective 的对偶, 但是在问题的处理上却复杂得多. 核心原因是我们在处理projective module 时是去寻找一个打到它的满射, 而injective module 则是需要寻找一个从它出发的单射. Zorn引理在这里具有很强的效果. Baer 判别法也是一个很有效的工具.

entry.title: Projective Module
entry.content:
一些很简单的projective module的内容, 比较有意思的是最后一个定理. 这个这个定理给出了local ring上的finite generated projective module一定是free的. 这是Kaplanski定理的一个特殊情况, 在这里的证明使用了Nakayama引理数维数.

(头图快不够了, 估计以后要用美少女来代替了 (ㄒoㄒ)/)

Projective Module

Definition 1. An RRR-module PPP is projective if for any exact sequence A→pB→0A\xrightarrow{p}B\to 0Ap​B→0 and f:P→Bf:P\to Bf:P→B, there exists a homomorphism g:P→Ag:P\to Ag:P→A s.t. the following diagram commutes:

The homomorphism p:A→Bp:A\to Bp:A→B will induce a homomorphism from Hom(P,B)\mathrm{Hom}(P,B)Hom(P,B) to Hom(P,A)\mathrm{Hom}(P,A)Hom(P,A), i.e. ggg is a lifting of fff.

First, we have: free module FFF is projective. Take a basis {fi}\{f_{i}\}{fi​} of FFF, from surjectivity of ppp, ∃ai∈A\exists a_{i}\in A∃ai​∈A s.t. p(ai)=f(fi)p(a_{i})=f(f_{i})p(ai​)=f(fi​). Then assign fif_{i}fi​ to aia_{i}ai​ and generate ggg from it.

Theorem 1. The functor Hom(P,−)\mathrm{Hom}(P,-)Hom(P,−) is exact if and only if PPP projective.

Proof

Proof. For the exact sequence 0→A→B→C→00\to A\to B\to C\to 00→A→B→C→0, we have the sequence 0→Hom(P,A)→Hom(P,B)→Hom(P,C)0\to \mathrm{Hom}(P,A)\to \mathrm{Hom}(P,B)\to \mathrm{Hom}(P,C)0→Hom(P,A)→Hom(P,B)→Hom(P,C) exact. B→C→0B\to C\to 0B→C→0 exact, so Hom(P,B)→Hom(P,C)\mathrm{Hom}(P,B)\to \mathrm{Hom}(P,C)Hom(P,B)→Hom(P,C) is surjective if and only if PPP projective. ◻

The projective module is a direct summand of a free module, i.e. PPP is projective if and only if ∃M\exists M∃M such that P⊕MP\oplus MP⊕M is free module. We first show the theorem:

Theorem 2. An RRR-module PPP is projective if and only if the exact sequence 0→A→B→P→00\to A\to B\to P\to 00→A→B→P→0 splits.

Proof

Proof. Consider the exact sequence $$0\to A\xrightarrow{f}B\xrightarrow{g}P\to 0$$

If PPP projective, take the exact sequence B→P→0B\to P\to 0B→P→0 and idP:P→Pid_{P}:P\to PidP​:P→P, it induces h:P→Bh:P\to Bh:P→B with g∘h=idPg\circ h=id_{P}g∘h=idP​. So the sequence splits.

Conversely, suppose every exact sequence 0→A→B→P→00\to A\to B\to P\to 00→A→B→P→0 splits. Consider any diagram

take the free presentation 0→Kerπ→F→πP→00\to \mathrm{Ker}\pi\to F\xrightarrow{\pi} P\to 00→Kerπ→Fπ​P→0 of PPP, by assumption

0→Kerπ→F→πP→00\to \mathrm{Ker}\pi\to F\xrightarrow{\pi}P\to 00→Kerπ→Fπ​P→0

splits. So ∃h:P→F\exists h:P\to F∃h:P→F s.t. h∘π=idPh\circ \pi=id_{P}h∘π=idP​. Since FFF is projective, ∃g:F→B\exists g:F\to B∃g:F→B s.t. f∘π=p∘gf\circ \pi=p\circ gf∘π=p∘g

Thus f=f∘π∘h=p∘g∘hf=f\circ \pi\circ h=p\circ g\circ hf=f∘π∘h=p∘g∘h, PPP is projective. ◻

Theorem 3. PPP is projective if and only if it’s a direct summand of a free RRR-module FFF.

Proof

Proof. If PPP is projective, the projective presentation 0→Kerπ→F→πP→00\to \mathrm{Ker}\pi\to F\xrightarrow{\pi}P\to 00→Kerπ→Fπ​P→0 splits, so F=P⊕KerπF=P\oplus \mathrm{Ker}\piF=P⊕Kerπ.

Conversely, using similar diagram chasing skill for

 ◻

A direct corollary is

Theorem 4. Direct summands and sums of projective modules are projective modules.

Proof

Proof. Omitted. ◻

We have shown that for projective module PPP and any module MMM, ExtR1(P,M)=0\mathrm{Ext}_{R}^{1}(P,M)=0ExtR1​(P,M)=0 in the Ext functor and Tor functor

Theorem 5. If ExtR1(P,M)=0\mathrm{Ext}_{R}^{1}(P,M)=0ExtR1​(P,M)=0 for every RRR-module MMM, then PPP is projective.

Proof

Proof. For a free(projective) resolution

⋯→F1→F0→P→0\cdots\to F_{1}\to F_{0}\to P\to 0⋯→F1​→F0​→P→0

Take M=Ker(F0→P)M=\mathrm{Ker}(F_{0}\to P)M=Ker(F0​→P), then ExtR1(P,M)=0\mathrm{Ext}_{R}^{1}(P,M)=0ExtR1​(P,M)=0. Take an element ξ∈ExtR1(P,M)\xi \in \mathrm{Ext}_{R}^{1}(P,M)ξ∈ExtR1​(P,M) given by the quotient of π:F1→M\pi:F_{1}\to Mπ:F1​→M. Since ξ\xiξ is zero, there is a map s:F0→Ms:F_{0}\to Ms:F0​→M s.t. π=s∘d1\pi=s\circ d_{1}π=s∘d1​, d1:F1→F0d_{1}:F_{1}\to F_{0}d1​:F1​→F0​. Thus F0=Kers⊕Ker(F0→P)=P⊕Ker(F0→P)F_{0}=\mathrm{Ker}s\oplus \mathrm{Ker}(F_{0}\to P)=P\oplus \mathrm{Ker}(F_{0}\to P)F0​=Kers⊕Ker(F0​→P)=P⊕Ker(F0​→P). ◻

For projective module, it is not necessary to be free. For example, for the ring Z/6Z\mathbb{Z} /\mathbb{6Z}Z/6Z, the ideal (2)(2)(2) is projective since (2)⊕(3)≅Z/6Z(2)\oplus (3)\cong \mathbb{Z} /6\mathbb{Z}(2)⊕(3)≅Z/6Z. Actually, any infinitely generated projective module over any Dedekind domain. We proof some weaker result:

Theorem 6. Any finite generated projective module MMM of a local ring RRR is free.

Proof

Proof. Take a minimal generating basis m1,…mnm_{1},\dots m_{n}m1​,…mn​ of MMM, here minimal means the minimal number of generators. Let F=⨁i=1nReiF=\bigoplus\limits_{i=1}^{n}Re_{i}F=i=1⨁n​Rei​, and φ:F→M\varphi:F\to Mφ:F→M with φ:∑riei↦∑rimi\varphi: \sum r_{i}e_{i}\mapsto \sum r_{i}m_{i}φ:∑ri​ei​↦∑ri​mi​. Take K=KerφK=\mathrm{Ker}\varphiK=Kerφ. If ∑rimi=0∈M\sum r_{i}m_{i}=0\in M∑ri​mi​=0∈M, pass it to the quotient M/mMM /\mathfrak{m}MM/mM, ∑rimiˉ=0∈M/mM\sum r_{i}\bar{m_{i}}=0\in M /\mathfrak{m}M∑ri​mi​ˉ​=0∈M/mM (Recall R/m⊗RM≅M/mMR /\mathfrak{m}\otimes_{R} M\cong M /\mathfrak{m}MR/m⊗R​M≅M/mM !). So ri∈mr_{i}\in \mathfrak{m}ri​∈m. Hence K⊂mFK\subset \mathfrak{m}FK⊂mF. Since MMM is projective, the sequence

0→K→F→M→00\to K\to F\to M\to 00→K→F→M→0

splits. Thus F≅M⊕KF\cong M\oplus KF≅M⊕K. Since FFF and MMM have same number of genenrators, dim⁡R/m(R/m⊗RF)=dim⁡R/m(R/m⊗RM)⇒F/mF≅M/mM\dim_{R /\mathfrak{m}}(R/\mathfrak{m}\otimes_{R}F)=\dim_{R /\mathfrak{m}}(R /\mathfrak{m}\otimes_{R}M)\Rightarrow F /\mathfrak{m}F\cong M /\mathfrak{m}MdimR/m​(R/m⊗R​F)=dimR/m​(R/m⊗R​M)⇒F/mF≅M/mM.
We have

R/m⊗RF≅F/mF≅R/m⊗R(M⊕K)≅(R/m⊗RM)⊕(R/m⊗RK)≅M/mM⊕K/mKR /\mathfrak{m}\otimes_{R} F\cong F /\mathfrak{m}F\cong R /\mathfrak{m}\otimes_{R}(M\oplus K)\cong (R /\mathfrak{m}\otimes_{R}M)\oplus (R /\mathfrak{m}\otimes_{R}K)\cong M /\mathfrak{m}M\oplus K/\mathfrak{m}KR/m⊗R​F≅F/mF≅R/m⊗R​(M⊕K)≅(R/m⊗R​M)⊕(R/m⊗R​K)≅M/mM⊕K/mK

Thus K/mK=0K /\mathfrak{m}K=0K/mK=0. Since KKK is finite generated, by Nakayama lemma, K=0K=0K=0. Thus F=MF=MF=M. ◻

A more stronger result can be seen in Projective modules over a local ring.
entry.summary:
一些很简单的projective module的内容, 比较有意思的是最后一个定理. 这个这个定理给出了local ring上的finite generated projective module一定是free的. 这是Kaplanski定理的一个特殊情况, 在这里的证明使用了Nakayama引理数维数.

(头图快不够了, 估计以后要用美少女来代替了 (ㄒoㄒ)/)

entry.title: Partition of Unity
entry.content:
微分流形初步的单位分解定理, 这个定理本质上是流形paracompactness所带来的结论. 它提供了一种通过乘上partition of unity函数的方式来将locally smooth的函数粘贴成global smooth的函数的方式. 下面的Whitney approximation theorem便是一个直接的例子.

Paracompactness of Manifold

First we give the construction of bump function. Here we use those function f∈C∞f\in C^{\infty}f∈C∞ s.t. f≡1f\equiv 1f≡1 on cubic C(1)ˉ\bar{C(1)}C(1)ˉ​ and f≡0f\equiv 0f≡0 outside C(2)C(2)C(2).

Consider the function f(t)={e−1tt>00t≤0f(t)=\left\{\begin{aligned} &e^{-\frac{1}{t}}\quad &t>0\\&0\quad &t\leq 0 \end{aligned}\right.f(t)={​e−t1​0​t>0t≤0​ then f∈C∞f\in C^{\infty}f∈C∞. Take g(t)=f(t)f(t)+f(−t)g(t)=\frac{f(t)}{f(t)+f(-t)}g(t)=f(t)+f(−t)f(t)​, g∈C∞g\in C^{\infty}g∈C∞ and g≡1g\equiv 1g≡1 for all t≥1t\geq 1t≥1, g=0g=0g=0 for all t≤0t\leq 0t≤0. Take h(t)=g(2+t)g(2−t)h(t)=g(2+t)g(2-t)h(t)=g(2+t)g(2−t), then h∈C∞h\in C^{\infty}h∈C∞ and h≡1h\equiv 1h≡1 on [−1,1][-1,1][−1,1] and h≡0h\equiv 0h≡0 outside (−2,2)(-2,2)(−2,2). Finally, just take the function to be φ=∏i=1nh∘ri\varphi=\prod\limits_{i=1}^{n}h\circ r_{i}φ=i=1∏n​h∘ri​, where rir_{i}ri​ are coordinate function.

Lemma 1. Let XXX be a topological space which is locally compact, Hausdorff and second countable, then XXX is paracompact.

Proof

Proof. First, we construct a sequence of open sets GiG_{i}Gi​ s.t. Gˉi\bar{G}_{i}Gˉi​ compact, Gˉi⊂Gi+1\bar{G}_{i}\subset G_{i+1}Gˉi​⊂Gi+1​ and X=∪i=1∞GiX=\cup_{i=1}^{\infty}G_{i}X=∪i=1∞​Gi​. Let {Ui}i∈I\{U_{i}\}_{i\in I}{Ui​}i∈I​ be a countable basis of XXX and Uˉi\bar{U}_{i}Uˉi​ compact. This can be shown by following:

We consider the set {Ui}i∈J\{U_{i}\}_{i\in J}{Ui​}i∈J​ with Uˉi\bar{U}_{i}Uˉi​ compact, we show that {Ui}i∈J\{U_{i}\}_{i\in J}{Ui​}i∈J​ also a basis of XXX. We only need to show ∀V∈{Ui}i∈I\forall V\in\{U_{i}\}_{i\in I}∀V∈{Ui​}i∈I​, V=∪UjV=\cup U_{j}V=∪Uj​ with j∈Jj\in Jj∈J. ∀x∈V\forall x\in V∀x∈V, ∃C\exists C∃C compact and x∈U⊂Cx\in U\subset Cx∈U⊂C. Then
Uˉ\bar{U}Uˉ compact, then x∈U∩V⊂U∩Vˉ⊂Cx\in U\cap V\subset\bar{U\cap V}\subset Cx∈U∩V⊂U∩Vˉ⊂C and U∩Vˉ\bar{U\cap V}U∩Vˉ compact.

Then we get such a countable basis: {Ui}i∈I\{ U_{i}\}_{i\in I}{Ui​}i∈I​ and Uˉi\bar{U}_{i}Uˉi​ compact.

Take G1=U1G_{1}=U_{1}G1​=U1​, Gk=U1∪⋯∪UjkG_{k}=U_{1}\cup \cdots\cup U_{j_{k}}Gk​=U1​∪⋯∪Ujk​​, let jk+1j_{k+1}jk+1​ be the smallest number s.t. Gkˉ⊂∪i=1jk+1Ui\bar{G_{k}}\subset \cup_{i=1}^{j_{k+1}}U_{i}Gk​ˉ​⊂∪i=1jk+1​​Ui​ and Gk+1=∪i=1jk+1UiG_{k+1}=\cup_{i=1}^{j_{k+1}}U_{i}Gk+1​=∪i=1jk+1​​Ui​. Then we have a sequence {Gk}\{G_{k}\}{Gk​} satisfying the condition in the beginning of proof. Gˉk−Gk−1\bar{G}_{k}-G_{k-1}Gˉk​−Gk−1​ is a compact set and Gˉk−Gk−1⊂Gk+1−Gk−2ˉ\bar{G}_{k}-G_{k-1}\subset G_{k+1}-\bar{G_{k-2}}Gˉk​−Gk−1​⊂Gk+1​−Gk−2​ˉ​.

For any k≥3k\geq 3k≥3, for the cover {Uα∩(Gk+1−Gˉk−2)}α∈A\{U_{\alpha}\cap (G_{k+1}-\bar{G}_{k-2})\}_{\alpha\in A}{Uα​∩(Gk+1​−Gˉk−2​)}α∈A​ of Gˉk−Gk−1\bar{G}_{k}-G_{k-1}Gˉk​−Gk−1​, we choose a finite subcover {Uα∩(Gk+1−Gˉk−2)}α∈A\{U_{\alpha}\cap (G_{k+1}-\bar{G}_{k-2})\}_{\alpha\in A}{Uα​∩(Gk+1​−Gˉk−2​)}α∈A​. This collection is obviously a countable and locally finite refinement of open cover {Uα}α∈A\{U_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha\in A}{Uα​}α∈A​. ◻

Partition of Unity

Definition 1. A partition of unity on MMM is a collection {φi}i∈I\{\varphi_{i}\}_{i\in I}{φi​}i∈I​ of C∞C^{\infty}C∞ functions on MMM s.t.

1. The collection of {Suppφi}i∈I\{Supp \varphi_{i}\}_{i\in I}{Suppφi​}i∈I​ is locally finite;

2. ∑i∈Iφi(p)=1\sum\limits_{i\in I}\varphi_{i}(p)=1i∈I∑​φi​(p)=1 for p∈Mp\in Mp∈M and φi(p)≥0\varphi_{i}(p)\geq 0φi​(p)≥0 for all p∈Mp\in Mp∈M and i∈Ii\in Ii∈I.

Now we give the partition of unity theorem.

Theorem 1 (partition of unity). Let MMM be a smooth manifold and {Uα}α∈A\{U_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha\in A}{Uα​}α∈A​ be an open cover of MMM. Then there exists a countable partition of unity {φi}\{\varphi_{i}\}{φi​} subordinate to the cover {Uα}\{U_{\alpha}\}{Uα​} with SuppφiSupp \varphi_{i}Suppφi​ compact for each iii.

Proof

Proof. We choose the sequence {Gi}\{G_{i}\}{Gi​} of MMM and G0=∅G_{0}=\varnothingG0​=∅. For p∈Mp\in Mp∈M, let ipi_{p}ip​ be the largest integer s.t. p∈M−Gˉipp\in M-\bar{G}_{i_{p}}p∈M−Gˉip​​. Choose αp\alpha_{p}αp​ s.t. p∈Uαpp\in U_{\alpha_{p}}p∈Uαp​​ and let (V,τ)(V,\tau)(V,τ) be a coordinate system centered at ppp s.t. V⊂(Uαp∩(Gip+2−Gˉip))V\subset (U_{\alpha_{p}}\cap (G_{i_{p+2}}-\bar{G}_{i_{p}}))V⊂(Uαp​​∩(Gip+2​​−Gˉip​​)) and τ(V)\tau(V)τ(V) contains cube C(2)ˉ\bar{C(2)}C(2)ˉ​.

Define ψp={φ∘τon V0otherwise\psi_{p}=\left\{\begin{aligned} &\varphi\circ \tau\quad & \text{on }V\\ &0\quad &\text{otherwise} \end{aligned}\right.ψp​={​φ∘τ0​on Votherwise​ φ\varphiφ is the bump function. Then ψp\psi_{p}ψp​ is a C∞C^{\infty}C∞ function on MMM which has value 1 on some open neighborhood wpw_{p}wp​ of ppp and has compact support in V⊂Uαp∩(Gip+2−Gˉip)V\subset U_{\alpha_{p}}\cap (G_{i_{p+2}}-\bar{G}_{i_{p}})V⊂Uαp​​∩(Gip+2​​−Gˉip​​). For each k≥1k\geq 1k≥1, choose a finite set of points ppp in MMM s.t. {wp}\{w_{p}\}{wp​} covers Gˉi−Gi−1\bar{G}_{i}-G_{i-1}Gˉi​−Gi−1​, the SuppφiSupp \varphi_{i}Suppφi​ form a locally finite family of subsets of MMM.

Take ψ=∑j=1∞ψj\psi=\sum\limits_{j=1}^{\infty}\psi_{j}ψ=j=1∑∞​ψj​, ψ\psiψ is a well-defined C∞C^{\infty}C∞ function and ψ(p)>0\psi(p)>0ψ(p)>0 for each p∈Mp\in Mp∈M. For i=1,2,…i=1,2,\dotsi=1,2,…, define φi=ψiψ\varphi_{i}=\frac{\psi_{i}}{\psi}φi​=ψψi​​. Then {ψi}\{\psi_{i}\}{ψi​} is a partition of unity subordinate {Uα}\{U_{\alpha}\}{Uα​} with {Suppφi}\{Supp \varphi_{i}\}{Suppφi​} compact. ◻

Theorem 2 (Whitney approximation theorem). Let MMM be a smooth manifold, and A⊂MA \subset MA⊂M a closed subset. Then for any continuous function g:M→Rg:M\to Rg:M→R which is smooth on AAA and any positive continuous function δ:M→R>0\delta:M\to R>0δ:M→R>0, there exists f∈C∞(M)f\in C^{\infty}(M)f∈C∞(M) so that f(p)=g(p)f(p)=g(p)f(p)=g(p) for all p∈Ap\in Ap∈A and ∣f(p)−g(p)∣<δ(p)\left| f(p)-g(p) \right|<\delta(p)∣f(p)−g(p)∣<δ(p) for all p∈Mp\in Mp∈M.

Here ggg smooth on AAA means ∃U⊃A\exists U\supset A∃U⊃A with a function g0=gg_{0}=gg0​=g on AAA and g0g_{0}g0​ smooth on UUU.

Proof

Proof. There is an open set U⊃AU\supset AU⊃A and a smooth function g0g_{0}g0​ defined on UUU s.t. g0=gg_{0}=gg0​=g on AAA. Let U0={p∈U∣∣g0(p)−g(p)∣<δ(p)}U_{0}=\{p\in U| \left| g_{0}(p)-g(p) \right|<\delta(p) \}U0​={p∈U∣∣g0​(p)−g(p)∣<δ(p)}. Then U0U_{0}U0​ is open in MMM and U0⊃AU_{0}\supset AU0​⊃A.

Now we construct a open cover of M−AM-AM−A, for any q∈M−Aq\in M-Aq∈M−A, let Uq={p∈M−A∣g(p)−g(q)∣<δ(p)}U_{q}=\{p\in M-A\left| g(p)-g(q) \right| <\delta(p)\}Uq​={p∈M−A∣g(p)−g(q)∣<δ(p)}. Then {Uq∣q∈M−A}\{U_{q}|q\in M-A\}{Uq​∣q∈M−A} is an open covering of M−AM-AM−A. Let {φ0,φq∣q∈M}\{\varphi_{0}, \varphi_{q}|q\in M\}{φ0​,φq​∣q∈M} be a partition of unity subordinate the cover {U0,Uq∣q∈M}\{U_{0}, U_{q}|q\in M\}{U0​,Uq​∣q∈M} of MMM and define a function on MMM by

f(p)=φ0(p)g0(p)+∑q∈Mφq(p)g(q)f(p)=\varphi_{0}(p)g_{0}(p)+\sum\limits_{q\in M}\varphi_{q}(p)g(q)f(p)=φ0​(p)g0​(p)+q∈M∑​φq​(p)g(q)

Since the support is locally finite, fff is smooth, f=g0f=g_{0}f=g0​ on AAA. Moreover, for any q∈Mq\in Mq∈M, we have

∣f(p)−g(p)∣=∣φ0(p)+g0(p)+∑qφq(p)g(q)−φ0(p)g(p)−∑qφq(p)g(p)∣≤φ0(p)∣g0(p)−g(p)∣+∑qφq(p)∣g(q)−g(p)∣<φ0(p)δ(p)+∑qφq(p)δ(p)=δ(p)\begin{aligned} \left| f(p)-g(p) \right| &=\left| \varphi_{0}(p)+g_{0}(p)+\sum_{q}\varphi_{q}(p)g(q)-\varphi_{0}(p)g(p)-\sum_{q}\varphi_{q}(p)g(p) \right|\\&\leq \varphi_{0}(p)\left| g_{0}(p)-g(p) \right| +\sum_{q}\varphi_{q}(p)\left| g(q)-g(p) \right| \\&<\varphi_{0}(p)\delta(p)+\sum_{q}\varphi_{q}(p)\delta(p)\\&=\delta(p)\end{aligned}∣f(p)−g(p)∣​=∣∣∣∣∣∣​φ0​(p)+g0​(p)+q∑​φq​(p)g(q)−φ0​(p)g(p)−q∑​φq​(p)g(p)∣∣∣∣∣∣​≤φ0​(p)∣g0​(p)−g(p)∣+q∑​φq​(p)∣g(q)−g(p)∣<φ0​(p)δ(p)+q∑​φq​(p)δ(p)=δ(p)​

◻
entry.summary: 微分流形初步的单位分解定理, 这个定理本质上是流形paracompactness所带来的结论. 它提供了一种通过乘上partition of unity函数的方式来将locally smooth的函数粘贴成global smooth的函数的方式. 下面的Whitney approximation theorem便是一个直接的例子.

entry.title: Kunneth Formula
entry.content:
这次是kunneth formula, 以及kunneth formula的直接推论, 同调万有系数定理和上同调万有系数定理. 没有学过代数拓扑所以基本上是从直观角度理解这个几个定理: 上同调万有系数定理应用比较直观, 直接给出了homology和cohomology之间的计算以及转换关系. 同调万有系数定理我觉得是在说这样一件事: 在改变定义同调时使用的系数环的情况下同调会发生什么样的变化. 这几个定理的证明说简单也简单, 也就是导出长正合列之后计算的事, 但是说复杂也很复杂, 这几个kernel都不是人算的. 这应该是一辈子只需要证明一次的定理, 使用比证明更加重要. P.S. kunneth formula 的证明可能有一点bug.(；′⌒`)

We talk about R−ModR-\mathrm{Mod}R−Mod in this section.

Universal Coefficient Theorem

Lemma 1. For a exact sequence 0→M′→M→M′′→00\to M'\to M\to M''\to 00→M′→M→M′′→0 and an object MMM, if M′′M''M′′ flat, then

1. 0→M′⊗N→M⊗N→M′′⊗N→00\to M'\otimes N\to M\otimes N\to M''\otimes N\to 00→M′⊗N→M⊗N→M′′⊗N→0 exact.

2. MMM is flat if and only if M′M'M′ is flat.

Proof

Proof. 1. We take a free presentation Rn→fNR^{n}\xrightarrow{f} NRnf​N of NNN and get the exact sequence 0→Kerf→Rn→N→00\to\mathrm{Ker}f\to R^{n}\to N\to 00→Kerf→Rn→N→0. Then we tensor the exact sequence 0→M′→M→M′′→00\to M'\to M\to M''\to 00→M′→M→M′′→0 to it and obtain the following commutative diagram:

Each rows and columns are exact. By the snake lemma, ggg is injective, thus 0→M′⊗N→M⊗N→M′′⊗N→00\to M'\otimes N\to M\otimes N\to M''\otimes N\to 00→M′⊗N→M⊗N→M′′⊗N→0 exact.

  1. Take an injection f:N′→Nf: N'\to Nf:N′→N and tensor 0→M′→M→M′′→00\to M'\to M\to M''\to 00→M′→M→M′′→0, we have the following diagram

Its rows exact by 1. If MMM flat, α\alphaα is injective thus α′\alpha'α′ injective, so M′M'M′ flat. If M′M'M′ flat, then α′\alpha'α′ is injective, from 5 lemma, α\alphaα is injective, thus MMM is flat. ◻

Theorem 1 (Universal Coefficient Theorem). For object MMM and a chain complex PPP, if PnP_{n}Pn​ and Imdn=dn(Pn)\mathrm{Im}d_{n}=d_{n}(P_{n})Imdn​=dn​(Pn​) flat for any nnn, then we have the following sequence exact

0→HnP⊗M→Hn(P⊗M)→Tor1(Hn−1(P),A)→00\to H_{n}P\otimes M\to H_{n}(P\otimes M)\to \mathrm{Tor}_{1}(H_{n-1}(P),A)\to 00→Hn​P⊗M→Hn​(P⊗M)→Tor1​(Hn−1​(P),A)→0

Proof

Proof. Notice that we have the exact sequence

0→Kerdn→Pn→Imdn→00\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{n}\to P_{n}\to \mathrm{Im}d_{n}\to 00→Kerdn​→Pn​→Imdn​→0

Tensor MMM on it, from the lemma above, we have exact sequence

0→Kerdn⊗M→Pn⊗M→Imdn⊗M→00\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{n}\otimes M\to P_{n}\otimes M\to \mathrm{Im}d_{n}\otimes M\to 00→Kerdn​⊗M→Pn​⊗M→Imdn​⊗M→0

It induces a short exact sequence of chain complex

0→Kerd⊗M→P⊗M→Imd⊗M→00\to \mathrm{Ker}d\otimes M\to P\otimes M\to\mathrm{Im}d\otimes M\to 00→Kerd⊗M→P⊗M→Imd⊗M→0

Use the long exact sequence theorem, since Hn(Kerd⊗M)=Kerdn⊗MH_{n}(\mathrm{Ker}d\otimes M)=\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}\otimes MHn​(Kerd⊗M)=Kerdn​⊗M, Hn(Imd⊗M)=Imdn⊗MH_{n}(\mathrm{Im}d\otimes M)=\mathrm{Im}d_{n}\otimes MHn​(Imd⊗M)=Imdn​⊗M, we have the long exact sequence

⋯→Imdn+1⊗M→Kerdn⊗M→fHn(P⊗M)→Imdn⊗M→gKerdn−1⊗M→⋯\cdots\to \mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}\otimes M\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{n}\otimes M\xrightarrow{f}H_{n}(P\otimes M)\to \mathrm{Im}d_{n}\otimes M \xrightarrow{g}\mathrm{Ker}d_{n-1}\otimes M\to \cdots⋯→Imdn+1​⊗M→Kerdn​⊗Mf​Hn​(P⊗M)→Imdn​⊗Mg​Kerdn−1​⊗M→⋯

For the short exact sequence

0→Imf→Hn(P⊗M)→Kerg→00\to \mathrm{Im}f\to H_{n}(P\otimes M)\to\mathrm{Ker}g\to 00→Imf→Hn​(P⊗M)→Kerg→0

we compute Imf\mathrm{Im}fImf and Kerg\mathrm{Ker}gKerg. From the snake lemma, we have the morphism Imdn+1⊗M→Kerdn⊗M\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}\otimes M\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{n}\otimes MImdn+1​⊗M→Kerdn​⊗M is δ⊗M\delta\otimes Mδ⊗M, where δ\deltaδ is the connecting morphism in the long exact sequence derived by 0→Kerd→P→Imd→00\to \mathrm{Ker}d\to P\to \mathrm{Im}d \to 00→Kerd→P→Imd→0, i.e.

⋯→Imdn+1→δKerdn→Hn(P)→0Imdn→⋯\cdots\to \mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}\xrightarrow{\delta}\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}\to H_{n}(P)\xrightarrow{0}\mathrm{Im}d_{n}\to \cdots⋯→Imdn+1​δ​Kerdn​→Hn​(P)0​Imdn​→⋯

Since −⊗M-\otimes M−⊗M is right exact, the diagram is commutative with exact rows

We have Imf≅Hn(P)⊗M\mathrm{Im}f\cong H_{n}(P)\otimes MImf≅Hn​(P)⊗M.

On the other hand, we consider the short exact sequence

0→Imdn→Kerdn−1→Hn−1(P)→00\to \mathrm{Im}d_{n}\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{n-1}\to H_{n-1}(P)\to 00→Imdn​→Kerdn−1​→Hn−1​(P)→0

Using the long exact sequence theorem of Tor\mathrm{Tor}Tor

⋯→Tor1(Kerdn−1,M)→Tor1(Hn−1(P),M)→Imdn⊗M→Kerdn−1⊗M→⋯\cdots\to \mathrm{Tor}_{1}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{n-1},M)\to \mathrm{Tor}_{1}(H_{n-1}(P),M)\to \mathrm{Im}d_{n}\otimes M\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{n-1}\otimes M\to \cdots⋯→Tor1​(Kerdn−1​,M)→Tor1​(Hn−1​(P),M)→Imdn​⊗M→Kerdn−1​⊗M→⋯

To compute Tor1(Kerdn−1,M)\mathrm{Tor}_{1}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{n-1},M)Tor1​(Kerdn−1​,M), we consider the short exact sequence

0→Kerdn→Pn→Imdn→00\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{n}\to P_{n}\to \mathrm{Im}d_{n}\to 00→Kerdn​→Pn​→Imdn​→0

Using the long exact sequence theorem of Tor\mathrm{Tor}Tor

⋯→Tor2(Imdn,M)→Tor1(Kerdn,M)→Tor1(Pn,B)→⋯\cdots\to \mathrm{Tor}_{2}(\mathrm{Im}d_{n},M)\to \mathrm{Tor}_{1}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{n},M)\to \mathrm{Tor}_{1}(P_{n},B)\to \cdots⋯→Tor2​(Imdn​,M)→Tor1​(Kerdn​,M)→Tor1​(Pn​,B)→⋯

Since Imdn\mathrm{Im}d_{n}Imdn​, PnP_{n}Pn​ flat, Tork(Imdn,M),Tork(Pn,M)=0\mathrm{Tor}_{k}(\mathrm{Im}d_{n},M), \mathrm{Tor}_{k}(P_{n},M)=0Tork​(Imdn​,M),Tork​(Pn​,M)=0. We have Tor1(Kerdn,M)=0\mathrm{Tor}_{1}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{n},M)=0Tor1​(Kerdn​,M)=0. Notice Kerd0=P0\mathrm{Ker}d_{0}=P_{0}Kerd0​=P0​, we finally have

0→Tor1(Hn−1(P),M)→Imdn⊗M→gKerdn−1⊗M0\to \mathrm{Tor}_{1}(H_{n-1}(P),M)\to \mathrm{Im}d_{n}\otimes M\xrightarrow{g}\mathrm{Ker}d_{n-1}\otimes M0→Tor1​(Hn−1​(P),M)→Imdn​⊗Mg​Kerdn−1​⊗M

So Kerg=Tor1(Hn−1(P),M)\mathrm{Ker}g=\mathrm{Tor}_{1}(H_{n-1}(P),M)Kerg=Tor1​(Hn−1​(P),M). Finally

0→HnP⊗M→Hn(P⊗M)→Tor1(Hn−1(P),A)→0\to H_{n}P\otimes M\to H_{n}(P\otimes M)\to \mathrm{Tor}_{1}(H_{n-1}(P),A)\to0→Hn​P⊗M→Hn​(P⊗M)→Tor1​(Hn−1​(P),A)→

◻

Theorem 2. For a PID RRR, the exact sequence

0→HnP⊗M→Hn(P⊗M)→Tor1(Hn−1(P),A)→0\to H_{n}P\otimes M\to H_{n}(P\otimes M)\to \mathrm{Tor}_{1}(H_{n-1}(P),A)\to0→Hn​P⊗M→Hn​(P⊗M)→Tor1​(Hn−1​(P),A)→

splits.

Proof

Proof. Notice that for PID RRR, the exact sequence

0→Kerdn→Pn→Imdn→00\to\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}\to P_{n}\to \mathrm{Im}d_{n}\to 00→Kerdn​→Pn​→Imdn​→0

splits. After tensoring MMM, the exact sequence

0→Kerdn⊗N→Pn⊗N→Imdn⊗M→00\to\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}\otimes N\to P_{n}\otimes N\to \mathrm{Im}d_{n}\otimes M\to 00→Kerdn​⊗N→Pn​⊗N→Imdn​⊗M→0

splits. So Kerdn⊗M\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}\otimes MKerdn​⊗M is direct summands of Pn⊗MP_{n}\otimes MPn​⊗M, i.e. the direct summands of Ker(dn⊗idM)\mathrm{Ker}(d_{n}\otimes id_{M})Ker(dn​⊗idM​). Quotient Imdn+1⊗M=Im(dn+1⊗idM)\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}\otimes M=\mathrm{Im}(d_{n+1}\otimes id_{M})Imdn+1​⊗M=Im(dn+1​⊗idM​), we have Hn(P)⊗MH_{n}(P)\otimes MHn​(P)⊗M to be the direct summands of Hn(P⊗M)H_{n}(P\otimes M)Hn​(P⊗M). ◻

Universal Coefficient Theorem for Cohomology

Theorem 3. For and object MMM and a chain complex PPP, if PnP_{n}Pn​ and Imdn=dn(Pn)\mathrm{Im}d_{n}=d_{n}(P_{n})Imdn​=dn​(Pn​) projective for any nnn, then we have the following sequence exact

0→Ext1(Hn−1(P),M)→Hn(Hom(P,M))→Hom(Hn(P),M)→00\to \mathrm{Ext}^{1}(H_{n-1}(P),M)\to H^{n}(\mathrm{Hom}(P,M))\to \mathrm{Hom}(H_{n}(P),M)\to 00→Ext1(Hn−1​(P),M)→Hn(Hom(P,M))→Hom(Hn​(P),M)→0

Proof

Proof. Similar to universal coefficient theorem for homlogy. ◻

Theorem 4. For PID RRR, the exact sequence

0→Ext1(Hn−1(P),M)→Hn(Hom(P,M))→Hom(Hn(P),M)→00\to \mathrm{Ext}^{1}(H_{n-1}(P),M)\to H^{n}(\mathrm{Hom}(P,M))\to \mathrm{Hom}(H_{n}(P),M)\to 00→Ext1(Hn−1​(P),M)→Hn(Hom(P,M))→Hom(Hn​(P),M)→0

splits.

Proof

Proof. Similar to the proof for homology. ◻

Kunneth Formula

Lemma 2. For two chain complex OOO, CCC, if the differential
morphism of OOO are the zero morphisms, then we have

Hn(O⊗C)=⨁i∈ZHn(Oi⊗C∙−i)H_{n}(O\otimes C)=\bigoplus_{i\in \mathbb{Z}}H_{n}(O_{i}\otimes C_{\bullet -i})Hn​(O⊗C)=i∈Z⨁​Hn​(Oi​⊗C∙−i​)

Proof. Notice that (O⊗C)n=⊕i+j=nOi⊗Cj=⊕i∈ZOi⊗C∙−i(O\otimes C)_{n}=\oplus_{i+j=n}O_{i}\otimes C_{j}=\oplus_{i\in \mathbb{Z}}O_{i}\otimes C_{\bullet -i}(O⊗C)n​=⊕i+j=n​Oi​⊗Cj​=⊕i∈Z​Oi​⊗C∙−i​ and the differential morphisms of O⊗CO\otimes CO⊗C are dn=∑i+j=n(−1)iid⊗djd_{n}=\sum_{i+j=n}(-1)^{i}id\otimes d_{j}dn​=∑i+j=n​(−1)iid⊗dj​, i.e. we only have the vertical morphisms. So
Hn(O⊗C)=⊕i∈ZHn(Oi⊗C∙−i)H_{n}(O\otimes C)=\oplus_{i\in \mathbb{Z}}H_{n}(O_{i}\otimes C_{\bullet -i})Hn​(O⊗C)=⊕i∈Z​Hn​(Oi​⊗C∙−i​). ◻

Theorem 5 (Kunneth Furmula). For two chain complex C,DC, DC,D, if CnC_{n}Cn​, KerdnC\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{C}KerdnC​, ImdnC\mathrm{Im}d_{n}^{C}ImdnC​ are all flat for n∈Zn\in \mathbb{Z}n∈Z, then we have the sequence exact

0→⨁i+j=nHi(C)⊗Hj(D)→Hn(C⊗D)→⨁i+j=n−1Tor1(Hi(C),Hj(D))→00\to \bigoplus_{i+j=n}H_{i}(C)\otimes H_{j}(D)\to H_{n}(C\otimes D)\to \bigoplus_{i+j=n-1}\mathrm{Tor}_{1}(H_{i}(C),H_{j}(D))\to 00→i+j=n⨁​Hi​(C)⊗Hj​(D)→Hn​(C⊗D)→i+j=n−1⨁​Tor1​(Hi​(C),Hj​(D))→0

Proof

Proof. Consider the exact sequence

0→KerdiC→Ci→ImdiC→C0\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{i}^{C}\to C_{i}\to\mathrm{Im}d_{i}^{C}\to C0→KerdiC​→Ci​→ImdiC​→C

Apply fuctor −⊗Dj-\otimes D_{j}−⊗Dj​ on it, we have

0→KerdiC⊗Dj→Ci⊗Dj→ImdiC⊗Dj→00\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{i}^{C}\otimes D_{j}\to C_{i}\otimes D_{j}\to \mathrm{Im}d_{i}^{C}\otimes D_{j}\to 00→KerdiC​⊗Dj​→Ci​⊗Dj​→ImdiC​⊗Dj​→0

To form a double chain complex, we define di:KerdiC→KerdiCd_{i}:\mathrm{Ker}d_{i}^{C}\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{i}^{C}di​:KerdiC​→KerdiC​ and di:ImdiC→Imdi−1Cd_{i}:\mathrm{Im}d_{i}^{C}\to \mathrm{Im}d_{i-1}^{C}di​:ImdiC​→Imdi−1C​ to be the zero morphisms. So we have the exact sequence of tensors

0→KerdC⊗D→C⊗D→ImdC⊗D→00\to \mathrm{Ker}d^{C}\otimes D\to C\otimes D\to \mathrm{Im}d^{C}\otimes D\to 00→KerdC⊗D→C⊗D→ImdC⊗D→0

Use the long exact sequence theorem, we have the long exact sequence

⋯→Hn+1(ImdC⊗D)→Hn(KerdC⊗D)→Hn(C⊗D)→Hn(ImdC⊗D)→⋯\cdots\to H_{n+1}(\mathrm{Im}d^{C}\otimes D)\to H_{n}(\mathrm{Ker}d^{C}\otimes D)\to H_{n}(C\otimes D)\to H_{n}(\mathrm{Im}d^{C}\otimes D)\to \cdots⋯→Hn+1​(ImdC⊗D)→Hn​(KerdC⊗D)→Hn​(C⊗D)→Hn​(ImdC⊗D)→⋯

From the lemma above

⋯→⨁i∈ZHn+1(Imdi⊗D∙−i)→⨁i∈ZHn(Kerdi⊗D∙−i)→fHn(C⊗D)→⨁i∈ZHn(Imdi⊗D∙−i)→g⨁i∈ZHn−1(Kerdi⊗D∙−i)→⋯\cdots\to \bigoplus_{i\in\mathbb{Z}} H_{n+1}(\mathrm{Im}d_{i}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})\to \bigoplus_{i\in \mathbb{Z}}H_{n}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{i}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})\xrightarrow{f} H_{n}(C\otimes D)\to \bigoplus_{i\in \mathbb{Z}}H_{n}(\mathrm{Im}d_{i}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})\xrightarrow{g}\bigoplus_{i\in \mathbb{Z}}H_{n-1}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{i}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})\to \cdots⋯→i∈Z⨁​Hn+1​(Imdi​⊗D∙−i​)→i∈Z⨁​Hn​(Kerdi​⊗D∙−i​)f​Hn​(C⊗D)→i∈Z⨁​Hn​(Imdi​⊗D∙−i​)g​i∈Z⨁​Hn−1​(Kerdi​⊗D∙−i​)→⋯

Via shifting the complex

{⨁i∈ZHn+1(Imdi⊗D∙−i)=⨁i∈ZHn(Imdi⊗D∙+1−i)=⨁i∈ZHn(Imdi+1⊗D∙−i)⨁i∈ZHn−1(Kerdi⊗D∙−i)=⨁i∈ZHn(Kerdi⊗D∙−1−i)=⨁i∈ZHn(Kerdi−1⊗D∙−i)\left\{\begin{aligned} &\bigoplus_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}H_{n+1}(\mathrm{Im}d_{i}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})=\bigoplus_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}H_{n}(\mathrm{Im}d_{i}\otimes D_{\bullet +1-i})=\bigoplus_{i\in \mathbb{Z}}H_{n}(\mathrm{Im}d_{i+1}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})\\ &\bigoplus_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}H_{n-1}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{i}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})=\bigoplus_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}H_{n}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{i}\otimes D_{\bullet -1-i})=\bigoplus_{i\in \mathbb{Z}}H_{n}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{i-1}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})\end{aligned} \right.⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​​i∈Z⨁​Hn+1​(Imdi​⊗D∙−i​)=i∈Z⨁​Hn​(Imdi​⊗D∙+1−i​)=i∈Z⨁​Hn​(Imdi+1​⊗D∙−i​)i∈Z⨁​Hn−1​(Kerdi​⊗D∙−i​)=i∈Z⨁​Hn​(Kerdi​⊗D∙−1−i​)=i∈Z⨁​Hn​(Kerdi−1​⊗D∙−i​)​

So we have the long exact sequence

⋯→⨁i∈ZHn(Imdi+1⊗D∙−i)→⨁i∈ZHn(Kerdi⊗D∙−i)→fHn(C⊗D)→⨁i∈ZHn(Kerdi⊗D∙−i)→g⨁i∈ZHn(Imdi−1⊗D∙−i)→⋯\cdots\to \bigoplus_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}H_{n}(\mathrm{Im}d_{i+1}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})\to \bigoplus_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}H_{n}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{i}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})\xrightarrow{f} H_{n}(C\otimes D)\to \bigoplus_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}H_{n}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{i}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})\xrightarrow{g}\bigoplus_{i\in \mathbb{Z}}H_{n}(\mathrm{Im}d_{i-1}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})\to \cdots⋯→i∈Z⨁​Hn​(Imdi+1​⊗D∙−i​)→i∈Z⨁​Hn​(Kerdi​⊗D∙−i​)f​Hn​(C⊗D)→i∈Z⨁​Hn​(Kerdi​⊗D∙−i​)g​i∈Z⨁​Hn​(Imdi−1​⊗D∙−i​)→⋯

Consider the short exact sequence

0→Imf→Hn(C⊗D)→Kerg→00\to \mathrm{Im}f\to H_{n}(C\otimes D)\to\mathrm{Ker}g \to 00→Imf→Hn​(C⊗D)→Kerg→0

We compute the short Img\mathrm{Im}gImg and Kerg\mathrm{Ker}gKerg. For the short exact sequence

0→Imdi+1→Kerdi→Hi(C)→00\to \mathrm{Im}d_{i+1}\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{i}\to H_{i}(C)\to 00→Imdi+1​→Kerdi​→Hi​(C)→0

we have the long exact sequence

⋯→Hn(Imdi+1⊗D∙−i)→Hn(Kerdi⊗d∙−i)→Hn(Hi(C)⊗D∙−i)→⋯\cdots\to H_{n}(\mathrm{Im}d_{i+1}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})\to H_{n}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{i}\otimes d_{\bullet -i})\to H_{n}(H_{i}(C)\otimes D_{\bullet -i})\to \cdots⋯→Hn​(Imdi+1​⊗D∙−i​)→Hn​(Kerdi​⊗d∙−i​)→Hn​(Hi​(C)⊗D∙−i​)→⋯

From the universal coefficient theorem

Hn(Imdi+1⊗D∙−i)=Imdi+1⊗Hn(D∙−i)H_{n}(\mathrm{Im}d_{i+1}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})=\mathrm{Im}d_{i+1}\otimes H_{n}(D_{\bullet -i})Hn​(Imdi+1​⊗D∙−i​)=Imdi+1​⊗Hn​(D∙−i​)

Hn(Kerdi⊗D∙−i)=Kerdi⊗Hn(D∙−i)H_{n}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{i}\otimes D_{\bullet -i})= \mathrm{Ker}d_{i}\otimes H_{n}(D_{\bullet -i})Hn​(Kerdi​⊗D∙−i​)=Kerdi​⊗Hn​(D∙−i​)

so

Imf=⨁i∈ZCoker(Imdi+1⊗Hn(D∙−i)→Kerdi⊗Hn(D∙−i))=⨁i∈ZHi(C)⊗Hn(D∙−i)=⨁i∈ZHi(C)⊗Hn−i(D)\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Im}f&=\bigoplus_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}\mathrm{Coker}(\mathrm{Im}d_{i+1}\otimes H_{n}(D_{\bullet -i})\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{i}\otimes H_{n}(D_{\bullet -i}))\\&=\bigoplus_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}H_{i}(C)\otimes H_{n}(D_{\bullet -i})\\&=\bigoplus_{i\in \mathbb{Z}}H_{i}(C)\otimes H_{n-i}(D)\end{aligned}Imf​=i∈Z⨁​Coker(Imdi+1​⊗Hn​(D∙−i​)→Kerdi​⊗Hn​(D∙−i​))=i∈Z⨁​Hi​(C)⊗Hn​(D∙−i​)=i∈Z⨁​Hi​(C)⊗Hn−i​(D)​

Similarly,

Kerg=⨁i∈ZKer(Kerdi−1⊗Hn(D∙−i)→Imdi⊗Hn(D∙−i))=⨁i∈ZTor1(Hi−1(C),Hn(D∙−i))=⨁i∈ZTor1(Hi−1(C),Hn−i(D))\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Ker}g&=\bigoplus_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}\mathrm{Ker}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{i-1}\otimes H_{n}(D_{\bullet -i})\to \mathrm{Im}d_{i}\otimes H_{n}(D_{\bullet -i}))\\&=\bigoplus_{i\in \mathbb{Z}}\mathrm{Tor}_{1}(H_{i-1}(C), H_{n}(D_{\bullet -i}))\\&=\bigoplus_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}\mathrm{Tor}_{1}(H_{i-1}(C), H_{n-i}(D))\end{aligned}Kerg​=i∈Z⨁​Ker(Kerdi−1​⊗Hn​(D∙−i​)→Imdi​⊗Hn​(D∙−i​))=i∈Z⨁​Tor1​(Hi−1​(C),Hn​(D∙−i​))=i∈Z⨁​Tor1​(Hi−1​(C),Hn−i​(D))​

◻

Theorem 6. For PID RRR, the short exact sequence splits.

Proof

Proof. Omitted. ◻
entry.summary: 这次是kunneth formula, 以及kunneth formula的直接推论, 同调万有系数定理和上同调万有系数定理. 没有学过代数拓扑所以基本上是从直观角度理解这个几个定理: 上同调万有系数定理应用比较直观, 直接给出了homology和cohomology之间的计算以及转换关系. 同调万有系数定理我觉得是在说这样一件事: 在改变定义同调时使用的系数环的情况下同调会发生什么样的变化. 这几个定理的证明说简单也简单, 也就是导出长正合列之后计算的事, 但是说复杂也很复杂, 这几个kernel都不是人算的. 这应该是一辈子只需要证明一次的定理, 使用比证明更加重要. P.S. kunneth formula 的证明可能有一点bug.(；′⌒`)

entry.title: Double Complex
entry.content:
这部分是double complex的一些内容, 内容比较少, 主要就是为了给后面的kunneth formula有个基本的定义啥的, 不考虑Tot函子的整体性质整块内容也没啥需要证明的, 摸了.👻 Stack Project 里面有很全的内容.

Double Complex

Definition 1. Let A\mathcal{A}A be an addictive category. A double chain complex AAA is given by {Ap,q,dp,q1,dp,q2}p,q∈Z\{A_{p,q},d_{p,q}^{1},d_{p,q}^{2}\}_{p,q\in\mathbb{Z}}{Ap,q​,dp,q1​,dp,q2​}p,q∈Z​ where dp,q1:Ap,q→Ap−1,qd_{p,q}^{1}:A_{p,q}\to A_{p-1,q}dp,q1​:Ap,q​→Ap−1,q​ and dp,q2:Ap,q→Ap,q−1d_{p,q}^{2}:A_{p,q}\to A_{p,q-1}dp,q2​:Ap,q​→Ap,q−1​ are morphisms of A\mathcal{A}A s.t. the following conditions hold:

1. dp−1,q1∘dp,q1=0d_{p-1,q}^{1}\circ d_{p,q}^{1}=0dp−1,q1​∘dp,q1​=0;

2. dp,q−12∘dp,q2=0d_{p,q-1}^{2}\circ d_{p,q}^{2}=0dp,q−12​∘dp,q2​=0;

3. dp,q−11∘dp,q2=dp−1,q2∘dp,q1d_{p,q-1}^{1}\circ d_{p,q}^{2}=d_{p-1,q}^{2}\circ d_{p,q}^{1}dp,q−11​∘dp,q2​=dp−1,q2​∘dp,q1​.

for all p,q∈Zp,q\in \mathbb{Z}p,q∈Z.

The definition of double cochain complex is similar.

Definition 2. For a double complex, its total complex Tot(C)\mathrm{Tot}(C)Tot(C) is given by Tot(C)n=⊕p+q=nCp,q\mathrm{Tot}(C)_{n}=\oplus_{p+q=n}C_{p,q}Tot(C)n​=⊕p+q=n​Cp,q​ with the differential morphism dnTot=∑p+q=n(dp,q1+dp,q2)d_{n}^{\mathrm{Tot}}=\sum_{p+q=n}(d_{p,q}^{1}+d_{p,q}^{2})dnTot​=∑p+q=n​(dp,q1​+dp,q2​). We can verify dnTot∘dn+1Tot=0d_{n}^{\mathrm{Tot}}\circ d_{n+1}^{\mathrm{Tot}}=0dnTot​∘dn+1Tot​=0.

Notice that in abelian category we may not have ⊕p+q=nCp,q\oplus_{p+q=n}C_{p,q}⊕p+q=n​Cp,q​. Then we can use ∏p+q=nCp,q\prod_{p+q=n}C_{p,q}∏p+q=n​Cp,q​ to substitute it. We can define the homology on the partial chain complex (Ap,q,dp,q1)(A_{p,q},d_{p,q}^{1})(Ap,q​,dp,q1​) and
(Ap,q,dp,q2)(A_{p,q},d_{p,q}^{2})(Ap,q​,dp,q2​).

Definition 3. For two complex C,DC, DC,D, we can define the tensor product of CCC and DDD as TotB\mathrm{Tot}BTotB, where Bp,q=Cp⊗DqB_{p,q}=C_{p}\otimes D_{q}Bp,q​=Cp​⊗Dq​, dp,q1=dp,q⊗idd_{p,q}^{1}=d_{p,q}\otimes iddp,q1​=dp,q​⊗id, dp,q2=(−1)pid⊗dp,qd_{p,q}^{2}=(-1)^{p} id\otimes d_{p,q}dp,q2​=(−1)pid⊗dp,q​, dnTot=∑p+q=ndp,q1+dp,q2d_{n}^{\mathrm{Tot}}=\sum_{p+q=n}d_{p,q}^{1}+d_{p,q}^{2}dnTot​=∑p+q=n​dp,q1​+dp,q2​.

Definition 4. For two complex C,DC, DC,D, we can define the Hom of CCC and DDD as TotB\mathrm{Tot}BTotB, where Bp,q=Hom(C−p,Dq)B_{p,q}=\mathrm{Hom}(C_{-p},D_{q})Bp,q​=Hom(C−p​,Dq​), dp,q1(f)(c)=(−1)p+q+1fdp−1(c)d_{p,q}^{1}(f)(c)=(-1)^{p+q+1}fd_{p-1}(c)dp,q1​(f)(c)=(−1)p+q+1fdp−1​(c), dp,q2(f)(c)=dpf(c)d_{p,q}^{2}(f)(c)=d_{p}f(c)dp,q2​(f)(c)=dp​f(c).

Proposition 1. Morphisms f:C→C′f:C\to C'f:C→C′, g:D→D′g:D\to D'g:D→D′ induce chain complex maps

f⊗f:C⊗D→C′⊗D′f\otimes f:C\otimes D\to C'\otimes D'f⊗f:C⊗D→C′⊗D′

Hom(f,g):Hom(C′,D)→Hom(C,D′)\mathrm{Hom}(f,g):\mathrm{Hom}(C',D)\to \mathrm{Hom}(C,D')Hom(f,g):Hom(C′,D)→Hom(C,D′)

If f≃f′f\simeq f'f≃f′ and g≃g′g\simeq g'g≃g′, then f⊗g≃f′⊗g′f\otimes g\simeq f'\otimes g'f⊗g≃f′⊗g′, Hom(f,g)≃Hom(f′,g′)\mathrm{Hom}(f,g)\simeq \mathrm{Hom}(f',g')Hom(f,g)≃Hom(f′,g′).

Proposition 2. If C≃C′C\simeq C'C≃C′, D≃D′D\simeq D'D≃D′, then C⊗D≃C′⊗D′C\otimes D\simeq C' \otimes D'C⊗D≃C′⊗D′, Hom(C,D)≃Hom(C′,D′)\mathrm{Hom}(C,D)\simeq \mathrm{Hom}(C',D')Hom(C,D)≃Hom(C′,D′).
entry.summary: 这部分是double complex的一些内容, 内容比较少, 主要就是为了给后面的kunneth formula有个基本的定义啥的, 不考虑Tot函子的整体性质整块内容也没啥需要证明的, 摸了.👻 Stack Project 里面有很全的内容.

entry.title: Homological Yoneda Lemma
entry.content:
Yoneda lemma的同调代数版本. 这是个很神奇的事情, 可以通过natural transformation 和Ext函子来计算一些函子的左导出函子. 整体的证明参考了论文The Yoneda isomorphism commutes with homology

Homological Yoneda Lemma

In Mod\mathrm{Mod}Mod category. Let 0→Rn−1→Pn−1→⋯→P0→A→00\to R_{n-1}\to P_{n-1}\to\cdots\to P_{0}\to A\to 00→Rn−1​→Pn−1​→⋯→P0​→A→0 be an exact sequence with Pn−1,…,P0P_{n-1},\dots,P_{0}Pn−1​,…,P0​ projective. Let TTT be an addictive functor. Define L~nTA=Ker(TRn−1→TPn−1)\tilde{L}_{n}TA=\mathrm{Ker}(TR_{n-1}\to TP_{n-1})L~n​TA=Ker(TRn−1​→TPn−1​). Then we have L~nTA=LnTA\tilde{L}_{n}TA=L_{n}TAL~n​TA=Ln​TA, the left derived functor of TTT.

Theorem 1. Let T:Mod→AT: \mathrm{Mod}\to \mathcal{A}T:Mod→A be an addictive covariant functor, TTT right exact and AAA be an module. Then there are natural isomorphism

Γ:Nat(ExtAn(A,−),T)→LnTA\Gamma:\mathrm{Nat}(\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A,-),T)\to L_{n}TAΓ:Nat(ExtAn​(A,−),T)→Ln​TA

Proof

Proof. We prove the functor HnH^{n}Hn commutes with Yoneda embedding, i.e. Nat(HnHom(A,−),T)→≅HnTA\mathrm{Nat}(H^{n}\mathrm{Hom}(A,-),T)\xrightarrow{\cong}H_{n}TANat(HnHom(A,−),T)≅​Hn​TA. Here AAA is a chain complex

⋯→An+1→dn+1An→dnAn−1→dn−1⋯\cdots\to A_{n+1}\xrightarrow{d_{n+1}}A_{n}\xrightarrow{d_{n}}A_{n-1}\xrightarrow{d_{n-1}}\cdots⋯→An+1​dn+1​​An​dn​​An−1​dn−1​​⋯

and

⋯→Hom(An−1,−)→dn∗Hom(An)→dn+1∗Hom(An+1)→⋯\cdots\to \mathrm{Hom}(A_{n-1},-)\xrightarrow{d_{n}^{*}}\mathrm{Hom}(A_{n})\xrightarrow{d_{n+1}^{*}}\mathrm{Hom}(A_{n+1})\to \cdots⋯→Hom(An−1​,−)dn∗​​Hom(An​)dn+1∗​​Hom(An+1​)→⋯

We compute Nat(HnHom(A,−),T)\mathrm{Nat}(H^{n}\mathrm{Hom}(A,-),T)Nat(HnHom(A,−),T).

Nat(HnHom(A,−),T)≅Nat(Coker(Hom(An−1,−)→Ker(dn+1∗)),T)≅Ker(Nat(Ker(dn+1∗),T)→Nat(Hom(An−1,−),T))≅Ker(Nat(Hom(Coker(dn+1),−),T)→Nat(Hom(An−1,−),T))≅Ker(TCoker(dn+1→TAn−1))≅Ker(Coker(Tdn+1)→TAn−1)=HnTA\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Nat}(H^{n}\mathrm{Hom}(A,-),T) &\cong \mathrm{Nat}(\mathrm{Coker}(\mathrm{Hom}(A_{n-1},-)\to \mathrm{Ker}(d_{n+1}^{*})),T)\\&\cong \mathrm{Ker}(\mathrm{Nat}(\mathrm{Ker}(d_{n+1}^{*}),T)\to \mathrm{Nat}(\mathrm{Hom}(A_{n-1},-),T))\\&\cong \mathrm{Ker}(\mathrm{Nat}(\mathrm{Hom}(\mathrm{Coker}(d_{n+1}),-),T)\to \mathrm{Nat}(\mathrm{Hom}(A_{n-1},-),T))\\& \cong \mathrm{Ker}(T\mathrm{Coker}(d_{n+1}\to TA_{n-1}))\\& \cong \mathrm{Ker}(\mathrm{Coker}(Td_{n+1})\to TA_{n-1})=H_{n}TA\end{aligned}Nat(HnHom(A,−),T)​≅Nat(Coker(Hom(An−1​,−)→Ker(dn+1∗​)),T)≅Ker(Nat(Ker(dn+1∗​),T)→Nat(Hom(An−1​,−),T))≅Ker(Nat(Hom(Coker(dn+1​),−),T)→Nat(Hom(An−1​,−),T))≅Ker(TCoker(dn+1​→TAn−1​))≅Ker(Coker(Tdn+1​)→TAn−1​)=Hn​TA​

The last to isomorphism is given by Yoneda lemma and right exactness, respectively. If we do not have TTT right exact, then we have Ker(TCoker(dn+1)→TAn−1)≅L~nTA\mathrm{Ker}(T\mathrm{Coker}(d_{n+1})\to TA_{n-1})\cong \tilde{L}_{n}TAKer(TCoker(dn+1​)→TAn−1​)≅L~n​TA. ◻

Proposition 1. Every natural transformation ϕ:ExtA1(A,−)→ExtA1(A′,−)\phi:\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A,-)\to \mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A',-)ϕ:ExtA1​(A,−)→ExtA1​(A′,−) is induced by a morphism f:A′→Af:A'\to Af:A′→A.

Proof

Proof. We have Nat(ExtA1(A,−)→ExtA1(A′,−))≅L~1(ExtA1(A′,−))(A)\mathrm{Nat}(\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A,-)\to \mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A',-))\cong \tilde{L}_{1}(\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A',-))(A)Nat(ExtA1​(A,−)→ExtA1​(A′,−))≅L~1​(ExtA1​(A′,−))(A). For 0→R→P→A→00\to R\to P\to A\to 00→R→P→A→0 a projective presentation of AAA,

L~1(ExtA1(A′,−))(A)=Ker(ExtA1(A′,R)→ExtA1(A′,P))\tilde{L}_{1}(\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A',-))(A)=\mathrm{Ker}(\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A',R)\to\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A',P))L~1​(ExtA1​(A′,−))(A)=Ker(ExtA1​(A′,R)→ExtA1​(A′,P))

From the long exact sequence theorem, we have

⋯→Hom(A′,P)→Hom(A′,A)→ExtA1(A′,R)→ExtA1(A′,P)→⋯\cdots\to \mathrm{Hom}(A',P)\to \mathrm{Hom}(A',A)\to \mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A',R)\to \mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A',P)\to \cdots⋯→Hom(A′,P)→Hom(A′,A)→ExtA1​(A′,R)→ExtA1​(A′,P)→⋯

Thus any natural transformation θ\thetaθ is mapped by an element fff in Hom(A′,A)\mathrm{Hom}(A',A)Hom(A′,A).

We omit the proof of the proposition: θ\thetaθ is indeed induced by fff. See Hilton & Stammbach. ◻
entry.summary: Yoneda lemma的同调代数版本. 这是个很神奇的事情, 可以通过natural transformation 和Ext函子来计算一些函子的左导出函子. 整体的证明参考了论文The Yoneda isomorphism commutes with homology

entry.title: Ext functor and Tor functor
entry.content:
这一节Ext函子和Tor函子, 大部分内容是上一章的直接推论, 唯一一个不平凡的定理择时对双函子Hom导出会得到相同的结果. 本节后半部分是关于这俩导出函子的计算的, 这俩函子的计算十分富有技巧性, 全写上来会很长. 最后部分的表格参考了Xiong Rui的小册子.

We consider category with enough projectives, e.g. Mod\mathrm{Mod}Mod.

Functor Ext\mathrm{Ext}Ext

Definition 1. The extension functor ExtAn(−,B)\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(-,B)ExtAn​(−,B) is given by right derived functor of HomA(−,B)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathcal{A}}(-,B)HomA​(−,B), the controvariant functor. I.e. ExtAn(−,B)=RnHomA(−,B)\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(-,B)=R^{n}\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathcal{A}}(-,B)ExtAn​(−,B)=RnHomA​(−,B).

Since Hom(−,B)\mathrm{Hom}(-,B)Hom(−,B) is a left exact functor, ExtA0(A,B)≅Hom(A,B)\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{0}(A,B)\cong \mathrm{Hom}(A,B)ExtA0​(A,B)≅Hom(A,B), by theorem in Derived Functors.

Proposition 1. If PPP is projective, III is injective, then ExtAn(P,B)=ExtAn(A,I)=0\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(P,B)=\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A,I)=0ExtAn​(P,B)=ExtAn​(A,I)=0.

Proof

Proof. For projective resolution O→PO\to PO→P, we have

ExtAn(P,B)=Hn(Hom(O,B))=0\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(P,B)=H^{n}(\mathrm{Hom}(O,B))=0ExtAn​(P,B)=Hn(Hom(O,B))=0

For ExtAn(A,I)\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A,I)ExtAn​(A,I), we check that Hom(−,I)\mathrm{Hom}(-,I)Hom(−,I) is an exact functor. Only need to show for exact sequence 0→A→B→C→00\to A\to B\to C\to 00→A→B→C→0, Hom(B,I)→Hom(A,I)→0\mathrm{Hom}(B,I)\to \mathrm{Hom}(A,I)\to 0Hom(B,I)→Hom(A,I)→0 exact. This is directly from the injectivity. So Hom(−,A)\mathrm{Hom}(-,A)Hom(−,A) is exact, and RnHom(−,I)=0R^{n}\mathrm{Hom}(-,I)=0RnHom(−,I)=0 for all n≥1n\geq 1n≥1. ◻

Proposition 2. For any exact sequence 0→B′→B→B′′→00\to B'\to B\to B''\to 00→B′→B→B′′→0 and object AAA, we have the long exact sequence

⋯→ExtAn(A,B′)→ExtAn(A,B)→ExtAn(A,B′′)→ExtAn+1(A,B′)→⋯\cdots\to\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A,B')\to \mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A,B)\to \mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A,B'')\to \mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n+1}(A,B')\to \cdots⋯→ExtAn​(A,B′)→ExtAn​(A,B)→ExtAn​(A,B′′)→ExtAn+1​(A,B′)→⋯

Proof

Proof. Immediate corollary from Derived Functors ◻

Functor Extˉ\bar{\mathrm{Ext}}Extˉ

Definition 2. The extension functor ExtˉAn(A,−)\bar{\mathrm{Ext}}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A,-)ExtˉAn​(A,−) is given by the right derived functor of HomA(A,−)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathcal{A}}(A,-)HomA​(A,−), the covariant functor, i.e. ExtˉAn(A,−)=RnHomA(A,−)\bar{\mathrm{Ext}}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A,-)=R^{n}\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathcal{A}}(A,-)ExtˉAn​(A,−)=RnHomA​(A,−).

Hom(A,−)\mathrm{Hom}(A,-)Hom(A,−) is a left exact functor so ExtˉA0(A,B)=Hom(A,B)\bar{\mathrm{Ext}}_{\mathcal{A}}^{0}(A,B)=\mathrm{Hom}(A,B)ExtˉA0​(A,B)=Hom(A,B).

Theorem 1. The bifunctor ExtAn(−,−)\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(-,-)ExtAn​(−,−) and ExtˉAn(−,−)\bar{\mathrm{Ext}}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(-,-)ExtˉAn​(−,−) are naturally equivalent.

Proof

Proof. We use induction to show ExtAn(−,−)≅ExtˉAn(−,−)\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(-,-)\cong \bar{\mathrm{Ext}}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(-,-)ExtAn​(−,−)≅ExtˉAn​(−,−).

For n=1n=1n=1, take an injective presentation 0→B→I→S→00\to B\to I\to S\to 00→B→I→S→0 of BBB and a projective resolution PPP of AAA. Since PnP_{n}Pn​ are all projective, we have

0→Hom(P,B)→Hom(P,I)→Hom(P,S)→00\to \mathrm{Hom}(P,B)\to \mathrm{Hom}(P,I)\to\mathrm{Hom}(P,S)\to 00→Hom(P,B)→Hom(P,I)→Hom(P,S)→0

exact. Applying the right derived functor, we get

Hom(A,I)→Hom(A,S)→ExtA1(A,B)→0=ExtA1(A,I)\mathrm{Hom}(A,I)\to \mathrm{Hom}(A,S)\to\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A,B)\to 0=\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A,I)Hom(A,I)→Hom(A,S)→ExtA1​(A,B)→0=ExtA1​(A,I)

exact. Derive the exact sequence 0→B→I→S→00\to B\to I\to S\to 00→B→I→S→0, we also have the exact sequence

Hom(A,I)→Hom(A,S)→ExtA1(A,B)→0=ExtˉA1(A,I)\mathrm{Hom}(A,I)\to \mathrm{Hom}(A,S)\to\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A,B)\to 0=\bar{\mathrm{Ext}}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A,I)Hom(A,I)→Hom(A,S)→ExtA1​(A,B)→0=ExtˉA1​(A,I)

From the above two exact sequence, ExtA1(A,B)≅ExtˉA1(A,B)\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A,B)\cong \bar{\mathrm{Ext}}_{\mathcal{A}}^{1}(A,B)ExtA1​(A,B)≅ExtˉA1​(A,B).

For n≥2n\geq 2n≥2, just replace these two exact sequence by

ExtˉAn−1(A,I)→ExtˉAn−1(A,S)→ExtˉAn(A,B)→ExtˉAn(A,I)\bar{\mathrm{Ext}}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n-1}(A,I)\to \bar{\mathrm{Ext}}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n-1}(A,S)\to \bar{\mathrm{Ext}}_{\mathcal{A}^{n}}(A,B)\to \bar{\mathrm{Ext}}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A,I)ExtˉAn−1​(A,I)→ExtˉAn−1​(A,S)→ExtˉAn​(A,B)→ExtˉAn​(A,I)

and

ExtAn−1(A,I)→ExtAn−1(A,S)→ExtAn(A,B)→ExtAn(A,I)\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n-1}(A,I)\to \mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n-1}(A,S)\to \mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A,B)\to \mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A,I)ExtAn−1​(A,I)→ExtAn−1​(A,S)→ExtAn​(A,B)→ExtAn​(A,I)

◻

For exact sequence 0→Rn−1→Pn−1→⋯→P0→A→00\to R_{n-1}\to P_{n-1}\to \cdots\to P_{0}\to A\to 00→Rn−1​→Pn−1​→⋯→P0​→A→0, where Pn−1,…,P0P_{n-1},\dots, P_{0}Pn−1​,…,P0​ are all projective, then

ExtAn(A,B)=Coker(Hom(Pn−1,B)→Hom(Rn−1,B))\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A,B)=\mathrm{Coker}(\mathrm{Hom}(P_{n-1},B)\to \mathrm{Hom}(R_{n-1},B))ExtAn​(A,B)=Coker(Hom(Pn−1​,B)→Hom(Rn−1​,B))

For exact sequence 0→B→I0→⋯→In−1→Sn−1→00\to B\to I_{0}\to \cdots\to I_{n-1}\to S_{n-1}\to 00→B→I0​→⋯→In−1​→Sn−1​→0, where I0,…,In−1I_{0},\dots, I_{n-1}I0​,…,In−1​ are all injective, then

ExtAn(A,B)=Coker(Hom(A,In−1)→Hom(A,Sn−1))\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A,B)=\mathrm{Coker}(\mathrm{Hom}(A,I_{n-1})\to \mathrm{Hom}(A,S_{n-1}))ExtAn​(A,B)=Coker(Hom(A,In−1​)→Hom(A,Sn−1​))

These are the corollary of theorem in Derived Functors

Functor Tor\mathrm{Tor}Tor

Definition 3. The torsion functor TornA(A,−)\mathrm{Tor}_{n}^{\mathcal{A}}(A,-)TornA​(A,−) is given by the left derived functor of the covariant functor A⊗A−A\otimes_{\mathcal{A}}-A⊗A​−, i.e. TornA(A,−)=Ln(A⊗A−)\mathrm{Tor}_{n}^{\mathcal{A}}(A,-)=L_{n}(A\otimes_{\mathcal{A}}-)TornA​(A,−)=Ln​(A⊗A​−).

Since A⊗−A\otimes -A⊗− is a right exact functor, we have Tor0A(A,B)=A⊗B\mathrm{Tor}^{\mathcal{A}}_{0}(A,B)=A\otimes BTor0A​(A,B)=A⊗B.

Similarly, we can define TorˉnA(−,B)=Ln(−⊗B)\bar{\mathrm{Tor}}^{\mathcal{A}}_{n}(-,B)=L_{n}(-\otimes B)TorˉnA​(−,B)=Ln​(−⊗B), here −⊗B-\otimes B−⊗B is a covariant functor.

Theorem 2. The bifunctor TornA(−,−)\mathrm{Tor}^{\mathcal{A}}_{n}(-,-)TornA​(−,−) and TorˉnA(−,−)\bar{\mathrm{Tor}}^{\mathcal{A}}_{n}(-,-)TorˉnA​(−,−) are naturally equivalent.

Proof

Proof. Similar to the proof of Ext\mathrm{Ext}Ext and Extˉ\bar{\mathrm{Ext}}Extˉ above. Note that every projective module is flat. ◻

Similary to functor Ext\mathrm{Ext}Ext, we have following conclusions. For the exact sequence 0→Rn−1→Pn−1→⋯→P0→A→00\to R_{n-1}\to P_{n-1}\to \cdots\to P_{0}\to A\to 00→Rn−1​→Pn−1​→⋯→P0​→A→0, where Pn−1,…,P0P_{n-1},\dots, P_{0}Pn−1​,…,P0​ are all projective, then

TornA(A,B)=Ker(Rn−1⊗B→Pn−1⊗B)\mathrm{Tor}^{\mathcal{A}}_{n}(A,B)=\mathrm{Ker}(R_{n-1}\otimes B\to P_{n-1}\otimes B)TornA​(A,B)=Ker(Rn−1​⊗B→Pn−1​⊗B)

For the exact sequence 0→Rn−1→Pn−1→⋯→P0→B→00\to R_{n-1}\to P_{n-1}\to \cdots\to P_{0}\to B\to 00→Rn−1​→Pn−1​→⋯→P0​→B→0, where Pn−1,…,P0P_{n-1},\dots, P_{0}Pn−1​,…,P0​ are all projective, then

TornA(A,B)=Ker(A⊗Rn−1→A⊗Pn−1)\mathrm{Tor}^{\mathcal{A}}_{n}(A,B)=\mathrm{Ker}(A\otimes R_{n-1}\to A\otimes P_{n-1})TornA​(A,B)=Ker(A⊗Rn−1​→A⊗Pn−1​)

Proposition 3. If AAA is flat, then for any object PPP, TornA(A,B)=0\mathrm{Tor}^{\mathcal{A}}_{n}(A,B)=0TornA​(A,B)=0. Similar for flat BBB.

Proof

Proof. For projective resolution P→B→0P\to B\to 0P→B→0, A⊗P→A⊗B→0A\otimes P\to A\otimes B\to 0A⊗P→A⊗B→0 is also exact. Thus TornA(A,B)=0\mathrm{Tor}^{\mathcal{A}}_{n}(A,B)=0TornA​(A,B)=0. ◻

Theorem 3. If object AAA has flat resolution F→A→0F\to A\to 0F→A→0,

$$F\quad \cdots\to F_{2}\to F_{1}\to F_{0}$$

then TornA(A,B)=Hn(F⊗B)\mathrm{Tor}^{\mathcal{A}}_{n}(A,B)=H_{n}(F\otimes B)TornA​(A,B)=Hn​(F⊗B)

Proof

Proof. We omit this proof and just use it. ◻

Computation fo Ext\mathrm{Ext}Ext and Tor\mathrm{Tor}Tor

Theorem 4.

  1. Hom(⊕iAi,∏jBj)=∏i,jHom(Ai,Bj)\mathrm{Hom}(\oplus_{i} A_{i},\prod_{j}B_{j})=\prod_{i,j}\mathrm{Hom}(A_{i},B_{j})Hom(⊕i​Ai​,∏j​Bj​)=∏i,j​Hom(Ai​,Bj​).

  2. ExtAn(⊕iAi,∏jBj)=∏i,jExtAn(Ai,Bj)\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(\oplus_{i}A_{i},\prod_{j}B_{j})=\prod_{i,j}\mathrm{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n}(A_{i},B_{j})ExtAn​(⊕i​Ai​,∏j​Bj​)=∏i,j​ExtAn​(Ai​,Bj​).

  3. (⊕iAi)⊗(⊕jBj)=⊕i,j(Ai⊗Bj)(\oplus_{i}A_{i})\otimes (\oplus_{j}B_{j})=\oplus_{i,j}(A_{i}\otimes B_{j})(⊕i​Ai​)⊗(⊕j​Bj​)=⊕i,j​(Ai​⊗Bj​).

  4. TornA(⊕iAi,⊕jBj)=⊕i,jTornA(Ai,Bj)\mathrm{Tor}^{\mathcal{A}}_{n}(\oplus_{i}A_{i},\oplus_{j}B_{j})=\oplus_{i,j}\mathrm{Tor}^{\mathcal{A}}_{n}(A_{i},B_{j})TornA​(⊕i​Ai​,⊕j​Bj​)=⊕i,j​TornA​(Ai​,Bj​).

Proof

Proof. Omitted. ◻

Now we focus on Z\mathbb{Z}Z-Mod\mathrm{Mod}Mod, ZnZ_{n}Zn​-Mod\mathrm{Mod}Mod, Q\mathbb{Q}Q-Mod\mathrm{Mod}Mod and Q/Z\mathbb{Q /Z}Q/Z-Mod\mathrm{Mod}Mod.

For Hom\mathrm{Hom}Hom, we have

Hom(↓,→)\mathrm{Hom}(\downarrow,\rightarrow)Hom(↓,→)ZmZ_{m}Zm​Z\mathbb{Z}ZQ\mathbb{Q}QQ/Z\mathbb{Q/Z}Q/Z
ZnZ_nZn​Z(m,n)Z_{(m,n)}Z(m,n)​000000ZnZ_nZn​
Z\mathbb{Z}ZZmZ_mZm​Z\mathbb{Z}ZQ\mathbb{Q}QQ/Z\mathbb{Q/Z}Q/Z
Q\mathbb{Q}Q000000Q\mathbb{Q}Q?
Q/Z\mathbb{Q/Z}Q/Z000000000?

For Ext\mathrm{Ext}Ext, we have

Ext(↓,→)\mathrm{Ext}(\downarrow,\rightarrow)Ext(↓,→)ZmZ_{m}Zm​Z\mathbb{Z}ZQ\mathbb{Q}QQ/Z\mathbb{Q/Z}Q/Z
ZnZ_nZn​Z(m,n)Z_{(m,n)}Z(m,n)​ZnZ_nZn​000000
Z\mathbb{Z}Z000000000000
Q\mathbb{Q}Q??000000
Q/Z\mathbb{Q/Z}Q/Z??000000

For ⊗\otimes⊗, we have

↓⊗Z→\downarrow\otimes_{\mathbb{Z}}\rightarrow↓⊗Z​→ZmZ_{m}Zm​Z\mathbb{Z}ZQ\mathbb{Q}QQ/Z\mathbb{Q/Z}Q/Z
ZnZ_nZn​Z(m,n)Z_{(m,n)}Z(m,n)​ZnZ_nZn​000000
Z\mathbb{Z}ZZmZ_mZm​Z\mathbb{Z}ZQ\mathbb{Q}QQ/Z\mathbb{Q/Z}Q/Z
Q\mathbb{Q}Q000Q\mathbb{Q}QQ\mathbb{Q}Q000
Q/Z\mathbb{Q/Z}Q/Z000Q/Z\mathbb{Q/Z}Q/Z000000

For Tor\mathrm{Tor}Tor, we have

Tor(↓,→)\mathrm{Tor}(\downarrow,\rightarrow)Tor(↓,→)ZmZ_{m}Zm​Z\mathbb{Z}ZQ\mathbb{Q}QQ/Z\mathbb{Q/Z}Q/Z
ZnZ_nZn​Z(m,n)Z_{(m,n)}Z(m,n)​000000ZnZ_nZn​
Z\mathbb{Z}Z000000000000
Q\mathbb{Q}Q000000000000
Q/Z\mathbb{Q/Z}Q/ZZmZ_mZm​000000Q/Z\mathbb{Q/Z}Q/Z

And for those arbitrary abelian group, just apply the structure theorem of finite generated abelian group.

entry.title: Abelian Category
entry.content:
就着懒狗的本性, abelian category的内容就不抄上来了, 反正abelian category都是大家熟知的一些内容. 😊

这里放上来从Stack Project 截出来的一段关于abelian category的内容. 不过Stack Project 里面关于Homological algebra的部分基本都没啥证明, 随便看看得了. /(ㄒoㄒ)/~~
